reviewText:
This game is utterly fantastic and the most striking thing about it is that it's free.  Generally F2P games always have some kind of gimmick or hook that gets players to pay out cash for perks or bonuses but not Path of Exile.  Being a huge fan of Diablo 2 I've been waiting for something to come along that captures what made that game so great back in its time and I've finally found it.

I've played other similar titles such as Torchlight 1 and 2 and while both of them are good games in their own right this still trumps them in nearly every way possible.  Enemy variation, item customization via the gem system, skill trees, difficulty, as well as area design this game has it all.  So far I've put in around 15 or so hours and I'm still nowhere near being done yet.

If you like these types of games and especially if you have friends to play with online this title is for you.

reviewText:
It starts of as a pretty nice game, but after you play for 100+ hours you start to understand how this game works.

The skill tree is not as impressive as it might seem, all characters end up being the exact same thing, 1 skill linked to support gems on a 6Link for the sole purpose of spamming in AOE. There is no skill, it's all about maxing out your character through gear to spam the same spell over and over again. You can play how you like, but the end game is just that.

Every single build will mass AOE spam, there is no alternative. The passive skill tree and every single gem is nullifed because of this, it is all essecially the same thing. Everything ends up being AOE, it doesn't matter if you're melee or a spellcaster.

Games like torchlight 2, the combat is more entertaining, you need to rotate multiple spells, its more combat focused.

This game lacks major combat enjoyment.

reviewText:
I will let my hours played speak for themselves.

Now that they're finally fixing the desync issues (once Awakening hits) there is absolutely nothing wrong with this game in my opinion.  It is (or will be shortly) as close to a perfect ARPG as you can get.  The level of customization is insane and the balance is extremely well done.  Devs are active and engaged with the community.

Love the pay model of buying only appearance changes.  Absolutely no way to make it pay to win or even pay for convenience.  I have given them more money than I care to admit.

It's amusing to note people say this is what Diablo 3 should've been.  Blizzard seems to have noticed as many of the features that have been rolled in (seasons, rifts, etc) all appear to be directly mirrored off how PoE implemented the same concepts.

reviewText:
“In my dreams I see a great warrior, his skin scorched black, his fists aflame.”

The most fascinating aspects of Path of Exile are the combat mechanics and skill tree, which provide countless possibilities for an individual character development and support all kinds of gaming styles. In addition the sinister atmosphere and believable presentation of Wraeclast in combination with the deep gameplay mechanics (e.g. crafting & currency system and various leagues) create an immersive gaming experience.

The other large appeal of PoE is the end-game with its randomly created instances, which can be accessed from the map room. The replayability profits enormously from the randomly generated maps, with room for countless variation in map modifiers, increasing the difficulty with each added attribute.

And for the masochistic gamers among us there is of course a hardcore mode. But upon the death of your hardcore character, he or she will be transferred into normal mode, so basically you can keep everything and continue your quest under non-hardcore rules. It should also be mentioned that there are several leagues in normal and hardcore mode, each of them providing different challenges and bonuses.

The only shortcoming of this game lies in the presentation and simplicity of the story. Although the different NPCs fill you in about the historic and current events in Wraeclast, no other means are used to bolster up the storyline.

You can read the pieced together history of Wraeclast on the following link.

http://pathofexile.gamepedia.com/History_of_Wraeclast

All in all PoE is a great example for an online action role-playing game, on a free-to-play basis, that can be completed, enjoyed and continued without spending a penny.

Fun fact: While 60 percent of donors were in the $10 range, the ‘diamond tier’, in which someone commits to $1,000 or more, found 183 supporters.
--

My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:

-	Atmosphere
-	Combat & Controls
-	Details
-	Tactical gameplay
-	Characters
-	Story

Based on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading:

-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

If the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).
--

Atmosphere: S-Rank

(The crack of bone, the spray of blood. Is there any sweeter music?)

Combat & Controls: S-Rank

(‘Shoot first, ask no questions.’ – Karui wisdom)

Details: S-Rank

(A skill tree with 1350 skills that provide passive bonuses to your character. What more do you want?!)

Tactical gameplay: S-Rank

(Good tacticians learn that consistency often trumps potential.)

Characters: B-Rank

Story: C-Rank
--

To conquer all achievements of Path of Exile, you will most likely spend several hundred hours, due to the very high complexity of the challenges. You have to play the single-player campaign with all seven characters at least once. In addition one of your characters has to reach level 90 on normal mode and another one level 90 on hardcore mode. Both require massive farming in the special map room.

The most interesting achievement is ‘All Ears’ and an appropriate guide can be found on the link below (thanks to Ionn).

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AqhAF_tCmlPtdDZwREQ4ZldSYTRkN2toVWlpOGduUGc&usp=sharing#gid=0

In addition there are several achievements based on pure chance, like ‘Beginner’s Luck’, ‘Left to Chance’, ‘Well-Connected’ etc. Good luck with them and may the odds be ever in your favour.

Achievement difficulty: 10 of 10

Common:
- Singleplayer [+2]
- Multiplayer [+1]
- Teamwork [+1]

Special:
- All Ears [+1]
- Capture the Flag [+1]
- Diminishing Returns [+1]
- Dream within a Dream [+1]
- Eternal [+2]
--

Path of Exile (PC) – Online action role-playing game + Hack & Slash
(Dark Fantasy) – 2013

reviewText:
Path of Exile won't be for everybody, it's unashamedly hardcore by design, and will take time to learn and master. But it's a better game than the competition, and it's free.

Not everybody will enjoy the kind of freedom the character building system gives, and the mistakes it allows, and I'm personally terrible at the overall vision required for constructing a build.
Not everybody will enjoy the darkness of the look and feel, or the difficulty and danger faced in progressing through the game, especially in hardcore mode.
But for those that do, the loot, skills and character building come together to create something great, in a game that's consistantly fresh with new updates of content and build possibilities.

reviewText:
Do you like loot? Do you like the ability to build your character and class almost any way you want? Do you want a game where the only purchasable items in the microtransaction shop are visual effects and won't help a uber rich person ruin the game? How about a very fleshed out damage and defense system? And finally, do like RPG's? Well then, this Free-2-Play Action RPG is for you! You get the ability to create a build that could be super tanky, super DPS oriented, or a mixture of both. There are so many Unique (Legendary) items with interesting stats and mechanics that you can be an adept Spellcaster that has mastered Lightning attacks, or a Berserker that has invested points in Fire and can crush his enemies with a menacing maul! Or maybe a Ranger who could freeze her enemies using her Ice based arrows! Or you could be the support, the one who masters Auras and gives huge buffs to themself and their party members! You can call upon Ancient Totems to do your dirty work, or raise Zombies and Skeletons, and maybe even raise a Ghost of a fallen enemy or two! With this game, the ways you can dispatch enemies is almost limitless, and the fact that this game is F2P is awesome. Path of Exile is constantly updated, and every few months a new content patch is implemented, so you can expect this game to live for a long time to come. The only problems I have with it are the always online DRM. Desync has accounted for many of my deaths, some of them in Races, and that is a giant bummer. If we were able to rely on our internet as little as possible, then I think this game could get a lot better. Trading is also hit and miss, as there is no universal currency. You pick up currency items, which are, for the most part, Orbs and Scrolls, and trade them up and down, depending on how rare they are and what  you need. All Currency is usable in the way that resources in other games such as Minecraft are. A Alchemy Orb will upgrade a normal item to a rare, and thus is worth more than a Transmutaion Orb which only goes to a Blue, etc. Overall, I love this game and will continue to create new builds and characters. I'd give PoE a 8/10 on my scale.




EDIT!!!
After playing this game for hours, I am dropping the naive rating of 8/10 to 6.5/10, JUST FOR THE ♥♥♥♥ING LAG. ♥♥♥♥ the lag. This game would be 100% more fun if your very life didn't depend on the server's synchronization with your client. 80% of my game deaths have been from a sudden lag surge from 50~ ping to 1000 ping, which occur VERY OFTEN. I really wish they would add in an offline mode or just fix the desynchronization issues, because they REALLY just kill the game after good sessions of wrecking faces in.

reviewText:
Path of Exile (PoE) definitely belongs amongst the best action RPGs that are currently out there. It offers a great amount of fun and challenge to players who are willing to spend time and effort in developing their character. There is a nice variety of classes to choose from and there are more than enough character slots available to try out different classes.

Player's adventure starts in Normal mode where encounters are quite easy and balanced for new and veteran players. However things start getting rough as the player gradually goes through the acts (there are currently 3 acts, act 4 to be added soon) and difficulty levels (Cruel and Merciless). After completing the game in all available difficulties, players get to experience the many available maps, which are generally used for leveling and farming gear.

The most fun thing about PoE is the freedom of choice regarding character development and selection of passive, and active skills. PoE's passive skill tree is extremely detailed and comprehensive. Almost all action RPGs allow for stat and skill allocation based on a character's archetype. However this level of detail is absolutely amazing. It pretty much allows for creating any type of character (mage, rogue, warrior and etc) with any class. Additionally, players are free to acquire and utilize any available skill and subsequently upgrade these (Naturally as long as their basic stats allow it).

One thing about PoE that somewhat bothers me is the restriction on respecifying skill points. Players acquire some passive refund points as a reward for certain missions, additionally there are Orbs of regret" that provide 1 passive refund point on use. However a full respec is virtually impossible except after any major patch release. So here's a word of advice to new players; plan ahead
date: spend your points wisely and don't be shy on reading the class forums. There is much useful knowledge to be gained that could save you a lot of time.\n\nI would absolutely recommend this game and invite you to try it. After all
recommended: Path of Exile is a free game and it won't cost you anything to experience it. Do try to buy some in-game (fluff)items to support the developers if you get hooked! (they really deserve it).\n\n-Sinner"

reviewText: I never thought I'd love Path of Exile as much as I love Torchlight 2. I love the idea of the huge passive skill tree and Final Fantasy style active skill system. Instead of providing a linear active skill tree, skills in Path of Exile are itemized onto Skill Gems". These gems can be activated by socketing them into your equipment. With the addition of a "Support-Gem"
date:
you can make your own unique skill. For example a simple fireball gem combined with "Multiple Projectiles" gem will turn your fireball skill into multiple fireballs. You can experiment and make your own active skills. There are thousands of combinations of skills and augmentations.

The most important thing -- the game is completely free! PoE offers ethical micro-transactions. There is no pay-to-win element. People can buy only cosmetic items for real-world money.

If you are going to give this game a try then remember to pre-plan your build or get ready to create new characters many times because "Math of Exile" punishes casual players."

reviewText:
Path of Exile is probably the right game for everyone who thought Diablo 3 was dumbed down too much compared to its predecessor; it's definitely the go-to ARPG for hardcore Hack 'n' Slashers with a crazy amount of possibilities when it comes to item & character builds and a huge passive skill tree.

It may seem a bit overwhelming at first but it's easy enough to figure out all aspects of the game on the go if you played other ARPGs before and the developers try to keep the replay value high with a constant influx of new leagues, events and content updates.

Pros:
- Free to play
- No pay to win
- Active community
- Devs listen to feedback
- Regular content updates and patches
- Great depth
- Lot of character build options

Cons:
- The depth can be overwhelming for new players
- Game mechanics might take some time getting used to
- Very rare small lag spikes

reviewText:
Grinding Gear Games' game design is quite simple: they made a game they themselves want to play. They tend and nurture it with parental-like care. They experiment, extrapolate, temper, and refine; constantly in pursuit of perfection, while having the humility to realize they will never reach it. Path of Exile is an ever-evolving masterpiece...

and GGG gives it to us for free... No pay-gates. No tedious time sinks. Free to play in purity. What's the catch then? How do they make money? Well, I like to think of GGG like that friend who offers to help you move or pick you up from the airport without you having need ask. You can't help but want to reward their generosity by buying them beer or pizza or paying for gas.

If you're a gaming enthusiast with any interest in the genre, you owe it to yourself to give Path of Exile a try. You quite literally have nothing to lose.

reviewText:
I'm nearing 1000 hours on the Steam version and figure I should add my input about the game.  I don't think I can recommend this anymore after the 2.0 patch.

Biggest complaints:
Game risk/reward does not exist.  They destroyed player defense and offense, increased monster health and damage across the board, and made the high-end maps drop even less.  So you prepare yourself, make the tankiest / decent character you can, roll the hard mods and then what happens?  You get nothing valuable in the entire run, no map to replenish your stock and are worse off than before you started.

Trading/economy is awful.  A literal hellhole.  There are players that scam people all day long for currency, work the market, and create monopolies all over the board; essentially, making it impossible for people to advance in the game depending on your build unless you give them all your currency.  Most of the time?  They're AFK!  Feels like a giant troll cesspool.
There is no auction place, the trading utilites are limited (like, one or two external sites that require additional external software to run in conjunction with PoE to properly operate)

The racing scene feels impossible to get into.  Not a twitch.tv streamer?  Good luck ever winning non-solo events!

Gameplay becomes stale.  After you create enough characters, look at enough builds on the forums, theorycraft your own, etc.  You realize something, you do the same thing for every character and only replace a few skills and links appropriately.  You have auto-casted defensive skills, spam one skill and run around while popping potions.  It's boring.  And this feels like the only way to be successful, not die and continue progressing.  And to really try something out of the norm, you better be rich or one of those people creating the monopoly or you'll just get stuck into a loop of poorly performing budget builds.

Last point on negatives: build enabling uniques, div cards, etc. are all too rare still.  They added these div cards to increase diversity and make it possible to farm for unique items or otherwise, but it's still useless.  The individual cards are as rare as the item you're trying to find, making them pointless to exist in the first place!  Seemingly zero influence on the economy of items they exist for.


After all that, the game does have good points, though.  It was a fun thousand hours for the majority.  It was worth the few hundred I donated to GGG.  I still play because it is still the best ARPG I've found.  If I had the opportunity to not try in the first place, I probably would take it.  It has been a very frustrating run with all the build nerfs, item nerfs, drop rate nerfs, and almost nothing in the opposite direction to make it feel like everything might not be getting worse.  They had a series called Build of the week" which may as well have been "nerf of the week" since they destroyed any build that appeared in it in the patch following the video release."

reviewText:
The real sequel to Diablo 2.

Diablo was fun. Diablo 2 was amazing, years past it's prime. Median mod brought life back to it as it aged. Diablo 3 was announced and everyone celebrated but as more and more came out about it gamer's hopes were dashed. All the brilliance that Blizzard North had created in the franchise, the things that made Diablo what it was, left the company with the people who originally made it. Thanks to some active, gamer-friendly, chatty developers in New Zealand, Path of Exile is as close as what would have been as crowdfunding and copyrights allow.

Pros: Free to play, reasonable system requirements, Diablo 3, wonderous innovations to the genre, very deep, infinite endgame, friendly chat-available developers, great events and leagues.

Cons: No classic Diablo story or characters, no offline/LAN play, complex trading economy, higher learning curve than more popular titles. No full tutorial.

Other: BRUTAL sometimes offensive and very mature" community in chat. Not a game

reviewText:
I truely respect the developers of Path of Exile. Not only have they made an awesome Diablo 2-esque free to play game. But they continue to release new content and even full fledges expansions without asking for a single dime. Not only that, but everything they have available for purchase is completely cosmetic. There is no pay to win mumbo jumbo in this one folks.

I have found many hours of enjoyment in this game and highly recommend it to anybody who enjoys top down games like Diablo & Diablo 2. I mean, might as well give it a shot. It's free, and it's fun.

I can't really seem to get into the story very well however. My main character is a witch. She was sentenced to death for you know, being a witch. Stealing peoples children and junk. But she escaped I guess and went into exile... Uh.. and now i'm trying to kill this dude that's responsible.. I don't know. All the bosses seem normal-ish at first, but then they turn into giant monsters. I don't really know what they are or what's going on. But the game is fun so I just roll with it. Guess i'll try and pay attention to the dialogue at some point. The story itself just seems sort of boring. Anyway, none of that ♥♥♥♥ matters very much. It's a good game, you'll be too busy leveling your character and building it to care about what's going on anyway.

Final Verdict: (4.3 out of 5)

reviewText:
One of my main problems with the Action RPG genre is that they tend to be repetitive and boring, which is something that Path of Exile managed to surprise me with, especially so when you consider it's Free to Play (and not Pay to Win -all in game purchases are vanity purchases or stash spaces). The game can seem a little overwhelming at first with it's enormous and deeply complex skill tree and its myriad of skills. The combination of the two mean that you can make hundreds, even thousands of different combinations of characters and still find fresh and new builds.

The game content (storyline) itself is rather short with it being easily possible to move through the story on all three difficulties within 10-15 hours before reaching the endgame content known as Maps. Maps have endless possibilities and are actually item drops much like weapons and armour which can also be enchanted using the various orbs in the game which also double as the currency as Path of Exile relies on a barter trade system rather than gold which is an interesting solution to the currency sink/inflation balance issue that plagues many games which rely on an economy.

Path of Exile also has multiple leagues running at once, there are standard and hardcore leagues which are the life-long leagues which will run till the servers shutdown for the game which have economies that never get reset. Along side the two long running leagues there are 'mutation' 4 month leagues which will add a flavour onto the standard gameplay model and also allow players to start in a fresh economy on a regular basis which gives newer players an equal chance to acquire wealth. Once these leagues come to an end the player's wealth will be moved to the respective parent league (standard/hardcore). Further more Path of Exile also challenges players in short term leagues known as races where players will compete to reach the highest level or the furtherest through the content with different modifiers on each short term race, from turbo enemies, to endless monster farming zones ranging anywhere from 30 minutes to 1 week. Players will earn points during these races which get added up over the course of a race season to earn valuable unique items as rewards.

That said, the thing that stopped me from playing the game was issues with ping spikes and lagging out, albeit most likely due to my connection, it seemed to be exacerbated by their lag compensation methods with consant desyncs and disconnects something I rarely suffer from in most other games I've played. That aside I would still strong recommend Path of Exile to anyone even remotely interested in ARPGs or looking for something new to play but don't want to spend much money.
-----------------------------------------------------
tl;dr
-F2P not P2W.
-Complex and deep. High replayability
-Interesting economy.
-Lag/internet issues seem to be more noticeable in this game compared to most other games.

reviewText:
One perfect example of how F2P games should behave.

It created a great diablo-like experience for people who felt that Diablo was lost when D3 was out, maintaining a completely free game save for cosmetic changes for your character, with different servers for different types of gameplay, like Hardcore servers and temporary servers.
It's expansions have proven themselves to be top-tier too.
If you like ARPGs, diablo-likes and good MMORPGs, go for it. It won't disappoint you.

reviewText:
This game is alot of fun. I never played diablo 2, but based on all the hype surrounding D3 I bought and played it. I couldnt get into it at all and got bored with it pretty fast. I saw this game got good reviews and was free so figured what the hell. Glad I did because it is great. For one thing, its completly free. No need to buy anything to progress in the game. I love the massive skill tree....it would have been incredible if they had an active skill tree like that as well. But on the flip side you have the skill orbs which adds an amazing amount of depth to the game. The further you go the more cool things you find that allow you to play around with the gem sockets to create some cool power effects. I love having cool spells to cast and the visuals in the game look great. No framerate drops or lagging ever.

Beating up on bad guys never gets old and finding those rare peices of loot is always a joy. I have no idea what the story is about and dont really care. I just want to level up and expand on that massive skill tree while creating some killer gear.

Highly recommend giving this game a look. You cant go wrong with free. This game could easily get retail value if they wanted. The folks at GGG should be commended for their efforts. Just a fantastic game.

reviewText:
Path of exile
Developer: Grinding Gear Games (GGG)
Grade 9/10
Review updated 3.11.2015 to take into account recent patches and expansions

First short review for those too well accustomed to modern hectic society:  Great game, although not flawless. Most importantly Path of exile is one of the most fair free to play games available.  As such there really is no good reason to not to try it.

Good/bad:
+ One of the most fair free to play games
+ Gameplay
+ Variety of viable character builds
+ Graphics
+ Economy (from stability point of view)
- Legacy items
- More content would be appreciated (more coming but slowly)
- Trading is difficult

Full review:
Before going to actual gameplay I want to emphasize the fact how fair this game is for a free to play game. Usually free to play games are more or less pay to win games but Path of exile is almost complete exception to this. Only pay to win feature of Path of exile is that with real money player can buy more stash tabs to which store stuff that can be shared by player’s characters in the same league.

The extra stash tabs naturally do give minor advantage but this really starts to have an effect only when the player has played the game for hundreds of hours.  Thus the money grabbing is aimed at those players who already have played and enjoyed the game a lot and thus one could claim that these players ought to pay a little to support such an enjoyable game. Even then the payment is one time as those bought tabs are permanent. Most importantly however the extra stash tabs are definitely not mandatory even after hundreds of hours of gameplay.

Next to the game itself. I am not expert when it comes to Action RPG games. As a prime example I never played Diablo 2 for which many people claim Path of exile to be better successor than Diablo 3 (which I haven’t played either). I would however claim Path of exile to be very good game. The main reason for this is the gameplay itself. It feels satiffying and the enemies are difficult but not too impossible. With many different viable builds in the game (more on this on nextt paragraph) can be replayed many times with different experience. with different characters (more on this later. As free game, you can easily go and verify this if you don't believe me.

Another good thing is the skill tree, which is identical for all the classes. (classes only have different starting positions in the tree). This allows creating very interesting builds for your characters and actually surprisingly many of them are viable. With viable I mean reaching the end game. Naturally the amount of end game builds is bit smaller but even it is surprisingly large (especially according to what I have heard to be the case in other action RPG games. The different builds also seem to relatively balanced except temporary anomalies created by game updates. These are fixed usually sooner or later.

Graphics are great which is always nice. The minimum graphical settings in this game are however quite high so low end PC owners may be in need of upgrade for playing this game (but as free game, try before upgrading)

As he last notable good thing (writing more would make this review way too long) I am going to mention economy. All I can personally say is that it seems to work. Why this is important is that I have heard that in many other RPG games the economy does not work but instead for example the inflation of prices becomes ridiculous and starts to affect the game negatively.

<The complaints about desynchronisation were here. Now GGG has finally introduced lockstep mode --> By default hit and movement detection works now like in MOBA's and RTS games, which is much much better than the original implementation. Desycnhronization issues are now problem only for those living really far from servers>

The main flaw of the game is legacy items in permanent leagues. Legacy items are items that are no longer obtainable other than by trading from other players who already own them (with extremely high price of course). Unfortunately most of the legacy items were created by weakening the normally obtainable versions of these items. As result people who have these legacy versions are in practice equipped with items that are too powerful (balance wise) and obtaining these items is difficult for new players.Legacy items are not a problem in temporary leagues but some people like myself who would like to play in permanent leagues are forced to choose between two bad options: living with legacy items or playing temporary leagues.

Second problem of Path of exile is lack story content. At the time of writing this the game has 4 chapters, which player has to pass in three difficulties before the end game". More acts are coming but the progress is painfully slow. It should be noted that the end game is well done and that lessens this problem. When 5th chapter comes I will consider the amount of content acceptable.

Third problem is that trading is impractical. The intended way to sell or buy items happens through trade chat
date: which is horribly flooded and yet very likely the people who would be willing to sell or buy what you want are not there when you are. There however are for example third party websites for listing items which helps a lot but GGG should really do something to fix this in-game.\n\nTo summarize. The game definitely has some flaws but the good sides very clearly overcome these problems. As a very fair free to play game there is therefore no reason for not trying this game."

reviewText:
Possibly a best Hack and Slash Action RPG game that is free to play without any pay to win things.
I have logged lots of hours, played it religiously I am well aware of it's pros and cons without being biased like many of the fans are. I still do believe this game is how Diablo 3 should have been.
But it still has few problems and is far from perfection.

Game play 7/10
-----------------------
+ Decision makings are important and need to research a lot about the game
+ Skill tree makes you think a lot.
+ Orb Trading system
+ Variety of skill gems
+ Free to play
+ No pay to win (except stash tabs)
-  Legacy items
-  Bad economy in permanent leagues
-  Balance changes that may destroy your builds.
-  Desync related problems that may get fixed later.
-  Map system that is too RNG based.
-  Frequent Nerfs and balance changes
- Act 4 requires reflexes and some mechanics that are unfriendly to newbies.
- Overtuned mobs and survivability is more important than Damage to level up or stay in HC ladder.

Graphis 7/10
------------
+ Dark and Gloomy atmosphere for mature players.
+ Realistic and not cartoony Graphics like TL2 or Diablo 3.
-  Arrows on rocks and do not disappear.
- Monsters stay on ground causing clutter.


Story 9/10
---------------
+A story that reminds you of relationship between England and Australia, where protagonist is exiled into a fearsome island named, Wreclast.
+Story is still being worked on, but really need to think and read everything in order to understand what is going on with the history of the island.
+Dependent on flavor texsts of unique items, npcs, and objects in level, it's more of a game where you have to pick up clues and solve the puzzle.
+Dark fantasy


Overall its a great game, but you may want to think about builds (if devs like it or not and pay lots of attention to patch notes if you are concerned about nerfs).

For a bonus.

PoE in Nutshell for pre-2.0
---------------------------------------
lvl 1-60= build check
lvl 60-80= gear check
lvl 80-90= luck check
lvl 90-100= patience check

Pot in Nutshell of 2.0
-------------------------------
Act 1- Act 3= ez mode
Act 4= Farming barrier until next difficulty.

GLHF.

reviewText:
500 hours in and no end in sight, speaks for itself. If you like ARPG, Path of Exile is the must play to end all must plays.

Pros
Economic design is intricate and thriving
Skill and character progression has depth beyond measure
Art, sound, and animation is beautiful
Customizable player housing
Perfect league and ladder design
Frequent large content updates
True free to play, no pay walls period

Cons
My singular issue with the game is how anticheat is handled. The methods used are extremely overbearing. All actions are controlled by a prediction system at the server level, and it is frequently confused. The result feels like lag but is actually the server forcing erronious corrections on your client. This has a large negative impact on the game.

Overall, 9/10. If they rethought and redesigned their anticheat system it would be 11/10.

Version 2.0 Edit:

Thought I'd update this and say they have now greatly improved, if not entirely fixed my concerns with the predictive server syncing. They've improved this from a few different angles. Firstly they've diversified their datacenter locations so you're much more likely to be on a low latency server. Secondly they've added a new primary data sync mode called lockstep which does not desync but only works well on low latency connections. Thirdly they've improved the overall responsiveness and accuracy of the predictive sync mode for high latency players. I was not the only one who felt the old predictive mode stifled this game's quality feel. They've heard our concerns and went to incredible lengths to do right for us. Game is now a serious, solid 11/10.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I honestly keep forgetting that this game is free. I put more hours into PoE than anything I've ever paid for. I highly recommend trying it. If you don't like it, you're out absolutely nothing. That being said, I actually started buying stuff just because I feel like they deserve it. Any game that I put hundreds of hours into deserves at least a bit of money from me, though I played the game for years without buying anything, and there is definitely no in-game advantage to doing so. Well, extra storage, but I went without it until about a week ago, so definitely not mandatory. Also, note that I played this game since the open Beta, but I just linked my Steam account to it in March of 2016, so the hours played is way below how much time I've actually put into it.

Anyway, it's fun, give it a go.

reviewText:
Woops, I didn't write a review on this one?
Thus I, too, am to blame this gem didn't/doesn't get the audience it deserves.
Yes, I also don't trust Free-to-Play games. I don't like the business model and I don't like the way their gameplay mechanics  function.
This, however, is one of the few games which are TRUELY free-to-play. This game is so fair you almost feel bad if you don't pay anything (maybe that's how they get you to spend your money... ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!). The things you can buy are purely decorative except for cheap extra space in your item chest (but it's already so big you don't even need it if you just play through the game once or twice).
So yeah, what you get absolutely for free here is a full game and there's nothing that feels cheap about it. It does have a rather classical feel, though. Actually, this is the only other game which gave me that Diablo II feeling. It's not the same and Path of Exile has a lot of good gameplay ideas and a whole fantasy world of its own, so don't expect a clone.
It's been a while now that I've played through it and I cannot really point out any details about what I liked especially and what bothered me, but I do remember I had a good time with this and if you liked Diablo II you should really give this one a try.
Because it has had some big updates and new content since I've stopped playing I might pick it up again soon. Maybe playing alongside you guys because co-op playing works quite well also :)

reviewText:
There's alot of pro and cons for this game.

-Better stat/skill system than the 100s of RPG's I played so far.
-True f2p, no pay to win stuff.
-Great graphics.
-Extremely long-term game, you can probably play for 100 hours+ and still want to try new builds.
-Tons of updates and player-made uniques.

There's also a few bad things about the game...

-Desyncs are horrible sometimes. The game can believe you are in Room C while you're still ''stuck'' in Room A and you can die easily because you do not see the monsters attacking you when this happens.
-You spend more time thinking about builds than playing the game, this is very true if you want a ''perfect'' character, because you need to plan everything or buy regrets orbs/ reset your bandits quest rewards ( Via in game currency. )

Overall this game is 100% worth trying, It has a good Diablo feeling and the way trading works is with Orbs/Items trading, there's no gold.

reviewText:
Path of Exile > Torchlight 2 & Diablo 3.

PoE is quite rare as it's one of the few true free to play games around, yet it offers plenty of content and depth compared to its competition which you have to pay for. Despite this the developers are maintaining a range of dedicated servers so even though you're forced to play online (just like D3), more people are able to have a decent online experience (they're even running an Australian server - something Blizzard has never bothered to do). In terms of visuals PoE might lack some polish, but it's refreshing to see the return of a gritty art style in a dark universe that isn't compromised so that more kiddies are able to play.

As it stands PoE is definitely worth a try if you're into dungeon crawlers or just looking for a quick bash at multiplayer with friends.

reviewText:
Path of Exile is a great diablo style RPG to play for a variety of reasons.
First of all it's free but even if it wasn't i'd still recommend it, second of all it adds enough interesting and unique gameplay mechanics that helps seperate itself from all the other action RPG's while still keeping that familiar style intact.
The first of these is the new healing system, instead of collecting dozens of potions you now only have 3-5 flasks that you fill up by killing enemies, meaning that you never run out of healing items as long as you have monsters to kill.
I feel that this helps the flow of the game a lot better than the usual potion system and it's a very welcome addition.

Next up is the new currency system, instead of collecting gold you collect scrolls and orbs that you earn from quest rewards and pick up as loot, this means that you can buy most items for only a few scrolls (Orbs on later levels) instead of lots of gold so you usually always have enough to buy what you want which is another nice addition.
Finally theres the gem system, all spells and magical abilities are now the gems that you equip on your armour, this means that they are now integral to gameplay as they also level up through usage, you can also create cool combinations through the gem links.

I'm also a big fan of the dark graphic style the game utilizes and the voice acting is proffessional enough so as not to sound cheesy.
All that along with great music and plenty of interesting areas to explore/monsters to kill that i'd recommend this to anyone that likes Action RPG's.

reviewText: One of the greatest concepts ever. The highly customizable builds makes this game sometimes a bit too much enjoyable actually, beside the fact the desync is a thing since release. Desync is really a thing you need to admit to at this game and if you can't you'll end up ragequitting anyways. Had the most fun I've ever had in a game with a build (Facebreaker Cyclone) which actually 'caused desync quite a bit and it didn't irritated me at all to be honest. The gem system is really worked out well and the replay value of endgame is amazingly high. Don't expect to see other mobs or other maps a lot, but expect to see dangerous and deadly combinations of these two a lot if you wan't to risk it! You need to make this game enjoyable yourself by asking help of others as well, the game is kind of hard to get into but once you're in it's hard to get out. This game is one of the definitions of addiction and dedication but it's totally worth it. I would highly recommend to start the game in a heroic league, the best way to learn is failing in this game!

reviewText:
Beautiful but dark (in tone) graphics with nice lighting effects. Excellent for a F2P game.

The mechanics are reminiscent of Diablo and Torchlight, but I think it wins over D3 and T2 any time. The passive skill tree is massive and allows you to take your character in totally different directions.

Trade is also more realistic, in that there is no gold but you have to trade things for various scrap parts. A refreshing twist.

reviewText: Diablo 2 has many imitators, but this one is the only worthy successor. Where other titles such as Torchlight and even Diablo 3 were content to dumb down the formula for casual players, Path of Exile retains all the character build complexity of it's inspiration. With custom ladders to keep the item economy fresh, there's always something to do. If you get bored of this game, stop playing ARPGs. It's all downhill from here.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The core game is pretty good with lots of character diversity and future potential, however the end game is currently rather lack luster having a high barrier to entry putting you largely at the mercy of the gods of RNG, who are never kind. This game suffers from some of the worst RNG issues i've ever seen, and generally is designed to cater to the super hardcore element.

The cosmetic microtransactions which fund the game are extremely expensive however there is no pay to win, unless you count buying extra stash space which to be honest is kind of necessary for any serious player; expect to dump $50-$100 on stash tabs if you get sucked into this game just to have room for your basic needs. The amount of storage space you get for free is rather pitiful; my advice is to wait for a stash tab bundle sale as they seem to happen on average once a month.

The biggest thing holding this game back is the antiquated trade system. Because of the bad RNG issue the only way to truely progress into end game is to trade for the things you need, if you try and play only self found you will get no where in end game very slowly. The developer promissed a robust trade system through their website back in beta but have so far failed to deliver and don't seem to have it as a development priority; the game suffers immensely because of this.

I'd recommend POE If you were a fan of diablo 2 and thought diablo 3 was terrible, you will probably enjoy this game. If you are the kind of person who can't handle complex character development then you will definately hate this game.

reviewText: Path of Exile is a free-to-play Action RPG in the style of Diablo 2.  The player character is foisted onto the terrible and foreign land of Wraeclast, an exile fighting all manner of monsters to survive.  Smash through waves of giant critters, evil demons, vile undead, and even worse in order to accumulate loot, power, and prestige.  It is the type of game that, at its core, is as simple as pointing and clicking on bad guys, yet is nuanced enough to be utterly compelling.  If you've ever fallen into a just one more level" trap with a game and then realized that you'd been playing far too long
date: then you know the allure of Path of Exile.\n\nCast as a game "for hardcore gamers

reviewText:
Great game, and completely free to boot.  If you love the Diablo game but weren't crazy about Diablo 3, I'd highly recommend checking this game out if you haven't already.

Pros
- The amount of customization and ways you can tweak your powers are limitless.  Whole builds can be made around single unique items that change your powers in interesting ways.
- Solid story and interesting world.
- Uses FF7 Materia system for powers
- Has really solid hardcore play for those who hate themselves (me)
- Powers fit the mood, no sparkly effect or silly sounds.
- Free!
- Purchase amounts are fair and are usable/tradable between characters.

Cons
- Skill tree can be off-putting for new players, you may have to look up some builds on the internet
- Actual gameplay can get repetative after a while, most of the fun is in building cool characters and trying to survive
- Bosses can be ruthless if you're not prepared, you can be easily carving your way through minions then get 1 shot by a unique boss (build defense and offense)

Overall I'd say the game's greatest asset is how much customization you can do in building and leveling characters.  The game's biggest flaw is easily the steep learning curve that newer players will face.  But if you stick with the game and do some research, Path of Exile offers hours of gameplay as you try to build an effective and interesting character.

reviewText:
SUMMARY: this game is, IMO, the best of its kind.
---
The latest free mini-expansion for Path of Exile releases later today so it seems like a good time for me to recommend it. On the face of it this game is your standard Diablo-clone - but even though it's not as flashy as Diablo 3, its depth, customisation and replayability ultimately make it rise above the competition.

The combat is fun and challenging. The game has a slow start (though that's one of the issues being addressed in today's expansion) but once the combination of skills and variety of environments becomes apparent it really comes into its own.

The skill tree is huge (really, absolutely massive) and offers countless build customisation options, which is in complete contrast to (e.g.) Diablo 3. You can combine skill gems to give your skills different effects -- sort of like runes in D3, but much deeper. I enjoy the loot and itemisation much more than other games in the genre too because of the possibility of crafting and improving any 'trash' item that drops.

The replayability is fantastic. New 'challenge leagues' are launched every few months which offer the option of an economy reset and always change the game in interesting ways. They also usually adjust the balance of the game (it can be a bit flavour-of-the-month-ish) regularly which means that different builds are enticing, and since builds play very differently this also helps replayability.

Then there's 'races' - short and challenging events of between 12 mins and three hours which offer a unique challenge and a nice way to get into competitive online gaming in a non-PvP setting. Race seasons run for six weeks or so every few months, with several events per day and unique rewards.

PoE is free-to-play but never pay-to-win. It has one of the best business models of any F2P game. Microtransactions are cosmetic or functional (e.g. visual skill effects, stash tabs) and the base offering is among the most generous I've seen in a F2P game. PoE's devs are responsive and down-to-earth, and regularly interact with players on reddit and the forums. Give them your money!

There are also plenty of little things - e.g. the game's take on health/mana flasks - which are so obviously better than the implementation in other games in the genre that it's very hard to go back to the impoverished versions of those features in other games.

There are still things that need improving - the trade system needs work, for instance, and desync can be a problem in certain circumstances. But these are only small negatives compared to the positives.

reviewText:
I played this game in the open beta phase in 2012. I must say i somehow didn't really get excited by it. I played it through once and just forgot about it. But now that it launched i picked it up again and i must say that its a good game. If you really want the most authentic diablo 2 game that is not diablo 2, this is it. Torchlight is fun but its more based on humour and bright graphics. And even though i enjoyed diablo 3 more than i should have, path of exile is the superior game. And it has the most fair free to play business model in the history of gaming, i would say.

I am really excited to see what future holds for this little gaming company, and especially this game. So if you are a fan of the genre PICK THIS GAME UP, you will NOT be dissapointed. 4,5/5

reviewText: This game is the true sucsessor to diablo 2. Great asthetic, a unique currency system dependant on the player created economy and a HUGE skill tree to help customize and create your own unique builds and playstyles. So far I am nearing 200 hours in Path of Exile and have yet to reach late game, because I spend my time making new builds and seeing how they fair against each other. It is a really fun ARPG so if you enjoyed diablo 2 3 or any other sort of ARPG like torchlight, give Path of Exile a try, it'll grow on you.

reviewText:
Path of Exile is a Hack and Slash game, It's F2P and you basically get an full game for no price at all.

You can however spend some money to get some Pay 2 look damn good effects.
What they offer is:  New Helmet models, Alternative Spell effects, small and cute pets and finally of what i know there are several kinds of Wing effects.

Anyways, to the basic works and system of the game.

The game is built on a Leveling system that gives your character one Passive skill point per level to put in an gigantic skill tree.

Wanna know how big this skill tree is?  It's makes the FFXII licence board look like a little plate of NOTHING.

You got so many option on this tree, you could create a Witch that hacks people with axes and swords.

Or an big, strong and scary marauder that walk around casting fireballs with a wand that's only the size of his fingers.

That is what makes this game so awesome, you can do whatever you want.
Want a fire casting and teleporting necromancer that has an army of dead at his command? Go for it, works just fine.

And never forget to ask in the general chat for advice... Though sometimes you can get some.. odd answers.

I won't say to much, cuz that's not how i do.

Know this.. The game might be slow in the beginning, but when you reach the mid to higher levels... This turn into a crash fest of chopping, freezing, burning and exploding every foul dark creatures that stand in your way.
But never let your guard down... Anything can kill you if you're not carefull.

*Edit: They also gradually add more content to the game, Skills, areas, expansions, visual effects etc.

All i gotta say is i really think this game is awesome and that it's totally free, yet It's got better quality gameplay than most games that cost over 20 Euro to play.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is irritatingly addictive.  I spent the weekend I got it playing it, instead of doing work I had intended to do.

This is an ARPG, and as such, there's not a whole lot of innovation when it comes to the actualy gameplay.  Overhead view, point a spam your mousebutton, pick up loot.  This isn't to say it doesn't do this well, as I found the experience to be enjoyable.  Intuitive controls, good challenge level (i.e., I'm not throwing my mouse in frustration of how hard it is, but I do sometimes have to think tactically, and retreat to defeat the horde against me).

Where this game earns its points is in its passive skill tree, it's gem-based skills (think materia from FFVII), and its in-game economy.

The passive skill tree can be a little overwhelming at first, since there is a LOT.  Once you spend a little time perusing it, and understanding how it works, it can start to seem kind of dull (how many times can you get a +10 to dex before you're looking for a little more, though there are other nodes to work with!).  Then, it hits you.  I can completely customize this character, and how it plays.  Want to be a duel-weilding lighning specialist?  Can do.  Fire-based summoner?  Alright, we can do that.  Want to just TANK with a really big axe?  We can do that, too.  The possibilities for different builds are bountiful.
Combine the skill tree with experience-gaining leveling skill orbs that can be socketed into items, and you have a great combination for customization.

The economy is another place where the devs took a different route than many others.  Money doesn't exist in this game.  Instead, you have barter system.  Normal items give you pieces of Wisdom scrolls (read: identify item), which eventually form into a whole scroll.  Whole scrolls also drop as loot, so this isn't your only means of ID'g an item.  Magical itmes might be worth augmentation shards, or transmutation shards, or other items.  While there is a formula to what the vendors give in exchange for what, it does teach you to think about loot grabs differently than other games.  In Diablo, or Torchlight for example, eventually normal items got left behind for magical, and even those eventaully weren't worth the inventory space.  In PoE, every item gets looked at individually.  Are you in need of ID scrolls?  Start picking up low-space normals.  Are you looking for a specific socket pattern for a weapon you want to try to craft?  Each item could be that thing you want!  Even that normal sword that, in other ARPGs would get left behind!  I personally found this to be a refreshing change of pace.
Even the meta-economy gets a little more interesting with no money.  What exactly is that unique piece of armor worth to you?

The best part of this game is its price.  Free.  And actually FREE.  Not, free to sign up

reviewText: Best dungeon crawler since Diablo ][ - it's legit, has elements of no controllable economy and the updated graphics put a whole different spin on an all too familiar gameplay.  The universal skilltree, is likely the best and most open part of the game where you can design any character to be exactly how you want them, and the ability to place any skill-gem on any type of character makes for infinate meta-game.\n\nFor free, it's a no brainer!

reviewText:
DO YOU LIKE FREE GAMES? DO YOU LIKE CARNAGE? DO YOU LIKE GORE? DO YOU LIKE A HELLISH GRITTY DARK STYLE GAME WITH TONS TO DO? Then look no further cheap skate this is the game for you....

A game with constant updates to always allow new things in the game, newer armor, higher levels, and accessories to make your character look devilishly good. Here's the catch... that's right the game is completely free, it has micro transactions with in the game but nothing that makes it pay to win. You join in and create a character and bam. You're all set.

You can pick character classes and emerse yourself in a skill tree so vast and huge that you wont know what the F*** to do with it. It has such a vast array of skills and abilities you'll get lost in it. So why do i recommend this game? WHY YOU ASK? Well simply... Its a free to play game, structured like a classic game that's brought enjoyment to millions of people, with stylish graphics and emersive gameplay. Pull up a chair and start collecting some loot, make your character amazing!.

reviewText:
Most underrated game of all time.

This game is by far the best game I have ever played. Not just because the content is great but because the developers listen, implement and change as the community casts its knowledgable opinion. They use everyone in the community as their non official staff and interact with them respectfully. The fact that all the content in this game is free is a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry.

Although this game has quite a challenging skill curve and is not too forgiving for new players I highly advise you give it a good go and buy something from the MTX store to support the best developers int he industry.

Pros
- Completely F2P
- Very challenging content
- Developers that listen AND implement change
- Hardcore option for people thjat want to become mentally unstable
- Neverending content releases
- Endless build possibilities

Cons
- Requires research and wiki for new players
- Confusing skill tree for new players
- Requires you to follow a build on the forums to really shine in the end game

Overall 10/10 my favourite game in this genre and probably all genres of all time. Try it!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A quality Free To Play Action RPG. It has a skill system similar to Final Fantasy VII's materia system, where you put a skill gem in a piece of equipment to gain access to new abilities, or passive bonuses that can link to other skill gems in the same piece of equipment that has linked slots. As well as getting 1 passive skill point per level up to spend in a skilltree reminiscent of Final Fantasy X's system, minus killing enemies for AP.\n\nYou get to play through a well made campaign with several acts without paying a dime. If you're a fan of games like Diablo II, Torchlight, etc, you should definitely give this game a try sometime.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=07B4SbJLPzk&list=PL0E56219EE956754E

Path of Exile: An action RPG similar to style and feel of great titles like Diablo 2. Path of Exile is a true marvel in its approach and achievement. Everything in the game is solid and simple but with a lot of its own ideas to make it different from most other ARPGs. From the colossal sized skill tree and open ended character building to skill gems and support gems and to the land of Wraeclast itself, it’s a unique enough experience that I haven’t encountered anything quite like Path of Exile before. Its non-standard approach is a nice breather from typical tropes of ARPGs and the fact that it works so well is a great achievement.  The game not only looks great but its sound design and overall ambiance is dark and dreary and very fitting of the setting. The story and lore of Wraeclast is quite disturbing and is quite interesting to unravel although, like most ARPGs its story is more akin to a movie rather than a true role-playing experience, where you make hard decisions and live out consequences of those choices. The game also suffers a bit with regards to its own character system, in that each character can potentially be the same, it loses its replay-ability a bit when compared to other ARPGs where characters are a class unto themselves with their own unique skills and spells and the skill tree in general will take a lot of careful planning and getting used to. Overall the experience of Path of Exile is solid and fun with the most frustration coming from the fact that it is an online game and with that comes some technical issues such as lag and issues from other players themselves. Personally, I would have gladly had paid whatever the asking price for this game, for it to be single player and online as optional. As a free-to-play title it does come with its own store which thankfully I can report does not have any content within it that feels like it has to be purchased in order to enjoy the game. Items in the are generally either cosmetic items, purely for looks or things like stash or character expansions, but they give you so many to start out with that these won’t feel like immediate needs or purchases ever. Path of Exile is a great ARPG, everyone can enjoy this game and it is simple and easy to get into and play and it at least offers 20+ of content for a first time through the entire game and it’s all completely free without any extra game content being behind a paywall.

-Double Thumbs up from Royial

Video Reviews can be found at: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

reviewText: Think of the elements that made Diablo II great, meddle it with Torchlight and add some new stuff: the result is Path of Exile, a game that is far too good to be a free to play game. You don't even need to play anything to become superior to the other players: the microtransactions are moslty cosmetics. There are paid games out there that don't have 10% of PoE's quality. Everything in this game is perfect; only the story is a little confusing and uninspiring, but the lore is pleasant. From the reliable community to the constant patches, this is a very friendly game, both for you and for your low-end PC. Without prolonging this review a lot more, let me just say that it took me about 20 hours to do a single playthough, which is a lot more than some AAA titles present. If you like ARPG, or just RPG, or even just a action game, there is no excuse for not to, at least, try this wonderful game. I give it a 92 out of 100. Best free to play game of 2013 and probably one of the best free to play games out there.

reviewText: Path of Exile is a truly free to play dungeon crawler that will make someone watching a video clip think it is from the Diablo" series. It isn't Diablo but it is in my opinion a better game than the Diablo series. There are six playable characters at the start and once the game has been beaten once and a side mission at the end of the game (that is along the required walking path but is optional) unlocks the seventh class.\n\nAll skills are based on gems that are tied to either Intelligence (Blue)
recommended: or Dexterity (Green). While gems of a certain color do highly favor one syle of gameplay (red = melee attacks most of the time) their are exceptions such as a red gem unlocking a "Totem"

column17: T keys. So when playing 8 skills are generally available with Mouse Left Click usually being bound to a hybrid of basic weapon melee attack and movement. Gems level up from the same experience your character gains. The gems just level up at different rates from your character class. The gems also have the same type of restrictions that items do such as minimum level and minimum stats (intelligence
column18: strength
column19: and dexterity) in order to equip them. This means that you could play as a Witch (Pure intelligence character build) and socket a red gem for a skill you'll never use. The gem will gain levels but it would be a better choice to stash the red gem for another character to use.\n\nGems/skills are modified by the extensive passive leveling system. Each level up and some quests give points to follow along the giant path available to you. The leveling "board" for lack of a better term is the same for all characters but different characters start at different places on the board. Here is a link for the seventh class
column20: the Scion
column21:
who starts in the very middle of the board. https://poebuilder.com/character/AAAAAgAA

The most interesting part of this game is that it does not have gold as a currency. There are something like 40 different currency items but they are acquired by trading in equipment. So everything you sell will come back as a currency that benefits in game as well as allowing trading with other players to be a lot more varied. Static prices don't really exist and almost all items that can be bought from NPCs are there for a specific reason.

This leads to the one flaw in the game
column22: inventory management. Trading with NPC vendors requires knowing some "recipes"
column23: certain combinations of items that give back the best payment. You start the game with 4 pages in your cross-character "stash" and the same inventory size for every character. There is no increasing character inventory size. You can increase your stash size but that does cost real life money. A 4 page stash means making stockpiles to fulfill recipe requirements and frequently selling. With more tabs a user could get better returns on their equipment. I'd like more stash pages but the game doesn't require having 4 to be a good player. It just severally restricts how many items you can horde. Hording wouldn't be a problem if there was any type of inventory sorting but there is not. Unfortunately at latter game interverals art assets get reused so it can be difficult to tell between the low level item you want to trade versus the high level item you've been saving.\n\nIn conclusion

reviewText: Henk Lostsword isn't your average exile.  He's on a path.  Is he on a path of good or of bad?  Well, that's up to you.\n\nIt's easy to criticize this game for what it is not.  It's not Diablo, despite what others may tell you, and the differences can be a letdown to some.  It's not a first-person shooter, nor is it a side-scrolling beat 'em up.  It's not particularly novel in its handling of top down, hack-slash-and-loot gameplay.  It's not an episode of Cheers" re-recorded on VHS with a two minute portion of "Scarecrow and Mrs. King" still left at the beginning that you have to wait through. reviewText:
Since this game is free, I will recommend it to anyone who have enjoyed these kinds of games in the past (Diablo, Torchlight, etc. etc.), as I have myself, I will say give it a go, knock yourself out.

Personally I grew tired of it fast (maybe it is a personal taste thing), even before finishing the main story the first time, the story is almost non-existant, and the gameplay is the same old Diablo-2-styled hack'n'slash with a few twists. As it is known for, it does a lot of things right that Diablo 3 for example did not, and that is why it has merit to be played.

As said, if you have enjoyed these kinds of games in the past, give Path of Exile a try. It is, however, not innovating the genre.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Path of Exile is an Free to Play online action role-playing game.  The player controls a single character from an overhead perspective and explores large outdoor areas and underground caves or dungeons, battling monsters and fulfilling quests from NPCs to gain experience points and equipment. All areas aside from the central encampments are randomly generated for increased re-playability. While all players on a single server can freely mingle in encampments, gameplay outside of encampments is highly instanced, providing every player or party with an isolated map to freely explore.  The game borrows heavily from the Diablo series, particularly Diablo II.

The graphics, sound, gameplay looks pretty good.

For more info:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x9-Wxfi1GIs

reviewText: The best ARPG on the market today, and it's FREE! No pay-to-win BS, either; all you can buy are cosmetic effects for spells and equipment, more stash space for hoarding items, and character slots. Most people won't even need to buy the latter, though, because you start with 24 slots for free. Endless character builds to try out, regular content updates and free expansions planned, on-going series of race events where you can compete and earn limited edition prizes... If you're a fan of the genre, there's no reason not to be playing this.\n\nMy only complaint with this game is the de-sync. They had to make the game always-online to prevent cheating, but then to accomodate the fast-paced, highly reactive and tactical combat, they're constantly syncing game state between your client and the server... Which, when their servers are overloaded by the huge influx of players on Steam, can often mean rubber-banding or lag in performing actions. It's most frustrating when playing hardcore, and a half-second delay can be the difference between life and death. They've been working hard to alleviate such problems, so hopefully they can make it better soon.

reviewText: I wish there was an option between recommended" and "not recommended" because that's the choice I would pick. After weighing all the pros and cons I have to "not recommend" this game in the end. Anyway
date: let's get into some details.\n\nARPGs are something I love to spend countless hours in. I love the grind and getting those sweet loot drops and then repeating this process over and over again until every slot is GG/BiS gear. I love trying different builds and min/maxing my stats as much as possible. All of this is possible in PoE. In fact
recommended: PoE is one of the most hardcore ARPGs out there. Many people have compared it favorably to D2. The build diversity in this game is absolutely insane due to the passive tree and skill gems
hoursPlayed: along with how these skill gems interact with each other by linking them in armor and weapons. If you want depth you absolutely will find it in this game - in fact at first I was quite overwhelmed. For example
voteText: when discussing "crits" in this game you need to keep in mind the difference between local critical chance on weapon attacks
helpfulPercent: critical chance on spells
votesHelpful: global critical chance
votesTotal: and critical damage multipliers (which I guess can be both local and global and can either be on attacks and/or spells). It is not like D3 in which critical chance is a flat additive percentage for everything. Anyway
votesFunny: this is only one example. The game is very nuanced and Google is your best friend if you don't understand something.\n\nSo yeah
commentsCount: I love all the depth in the game
column16: so why am I not recommending this? Simple. The endgame trading is absolutely horrendous. I reached the beginning of endgame (level 70) and I should just grind low level maps or areas like merciless Dried Lake for loot and currency. Well...that doesn't really work. In order to get the best items for your build you NEED to trade. But since there's no gold in the game it's difficult to judge whether an item is worth 1 Chaos or 2 Chaos or whatever other currency. This is especially true for new players like me who want to get started in trading but the entire buisness is already monopolized by the streamers and other "pro players". The loot drops are terrible - the chance of finding a rare or unique that's worth a few Chaos or Exalted is extremely low. Maybe if you do a pure MF build it'll be better
column17: but my point is
column18: I just want to use my build and farm enemies and find good endgame gear. There would be no point in build diversity if you have to use a MF build just to have a chance of finding some BiS stuff.\n\nSo here I am
column19: at endgame with a few Chaos orbs and zero Exalted. I want to buy some items by using poe.trade (community trade site) but most people are not online and/or they are fake accounts. Using trade chat is a joke - just full of spammers and people trying to lowball you for profit. And how am I suppose to sell anything? Use poe.trade? Set up a shop on the forums? Very tedious and troublesome because not only do I have to jump through hoops to do it
column20: there's no gurantee anyone will buy my stuff or offer fair prices. I want to play an ARPG not "trade simulator extreme edition".\n\ntl;dr - The biggest turn off for me is the endgame trading. It's absolutely garbage and DAS (dumb as ♥♥♥♥). The rest of the game is quite good and I did enjoy it. But we all know for games like this the endgame will either make or break the game. I hope the developers will add in a streamlined in-game trading system in the near future
column21: but until then
column22: I will not be coming back."

reviewText:
Didn't like Diablo III ? Well heres the better Diablo III :P A hack and slay that is free to play but NOT pay to win, and that's the awesome thing about it.
The only problem, the weapon skins are way too expensive, so you will just buy one or two in your life xD

Other than that, the passive skill tree is ♥♥♥♥ing huge.
(Be aware, the whole picture is 16135 × 15300 and may slow down your pc xD)

http://www.pathofexile.com/passive-skill-tree

You can basically do whatever you want with each of the 7 classes.

You also have skill-gems (like the ones in Final Fantasy 7), that you can put on your armor to level them up and link them together to get better effects.
Right now this game has 3 chapters with another possibly on the way.

If you are a fan of any hack and slay, please give it a try. It's not the best visually, but it is an improvement over Diablo II, that doesn't look too bad.

reviewText:
Truly a fantastic game, best of it's type.
This game is far better than Diablo 3 could have ever hoped to be, however just like Diablo 3 it becomes extremely repetitive after just a short while, unfortunate.
Ups against Diablo 3:
Better class design
Better customization options
Better and far more exciting spells to choose from
Better leveling system, including spell levels
Better NPC's, It's clear there was a lot more work put into the NPC's on this, voice acting, design and personality than there was on Diablo 3
Better community, it seems on this people are far more friendly then they were on Diablo 3.

Downs against Diablo 3:
There is only one gender for each class

reviewText: 12/15/2013 - This is a great action RPG that I consider to be on the same level as genre epics like Diablo, Torchlight, and Titan Quest in regards to gameplay, fun, design, and visuals.  I'm sure you'll find the same praise in most of the Steam and online reviews.  However, I cannot wholly recommend the game because of the continuous problems with lag or as the community often refers to it:  desync.  No, it's not a problem with my computer or connection.  It's widespread and encountered often.  I've lost 2 hardcore characters to desync; it's not fun when all the time you invested into your character is thrown away due to lag.  The problem is that everything has to run online through their server (no offline play), and due to how well they developed the game, there are too many people playing on the server resources currently in place.  If they made it so that you could play a character offline or seriously revamped the network code and server resources, this would be a perfect game.  In its current state, as good as the game is, I find it too frustrating to consistently enjoy.  The devs are very good about listening to the community and improving/updating the game, so hopefully it's only a matter of time before the desync issues are fixed.

reviewText:
Poor man's (free to play) Diablo. The gem/skill system is interesting, which is reminicent of Final Fantasy 7's materia system. The graphics are decent enough and there's plenty of loot to be had and depth in combining skills by linking slots together (ala support materia in FF7). However...

The always-online aspect of this game is not so great, though. Rubberbanding is fairly consistent, even with a low ping. The game itself is the gatekeeper for your fun, dictating how viable you are by not only gear drops, but what skills you have access to. The time-sink basis of the game is a bit of a turn off. Expect to carefully plan a character and have it nerfed to bejesus, thereby ending your character as many have been so vocal about online, since resetting a character's skills is basically impossible. The currency system favors NPCs at every level, and the loot system is a free-for-all grabfest, so play with people you trust.

If you play this game, play with a group. Play with friends. Solo I can imagine is a nightmare considering how tempermental drops can be, but crushing things in a group and splitting loot means there's fun times for those seeking them.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought and played Diablo 3 but I really wanted Path Of Exile.

Skill gems and the shared passive skill LANDSCAPE (not tree) make character builds and gearing a more involved and personal experience, making the game replayable in a way that truly matters--not that the truly randomly-generated levels and endgame Maps don't keep you on your toes even when you're at full power.

Playing as a newbie can be intimidating, but there's a joy to be had in doing your own research and owning your builds. Don't pay attention to the hardcore players; if you're looking for a good, rough dungeon romp as you make the best of your gear, this game delivers in spades.

EDIT: I've spent 40 hours on POE in just two weeks. In the three months I played D3, I racked up only 80 hours of gametime. That should be telling.

reviewText:
Path of Exile is actually one of the BEST MMOs I've ever played. The combat itself isn't really different from any other MMORPG's, but the gem system and how they give you skills is definitely pretty unique. You aren't bombarded by microtransactions, if at all, and I like how it works on an instance system.

So far the game hasn't been overly hard, but I've died here and there. There are a few especially hard parts that I really liked, like the final boss of Act 1.

The community is definitely a big part of the game. Most people in chat are kind enough to give new players help, and having the trade chat helps people trade stuff for other stuff.

What I really love is the flexibility of each character, due to the passive skills. It's totally viable to make your duelist magic-focused, ranged, or even all-around.

Graphics-wise, the game looks pretty great. The places in game are beautiful, especially the forest areas in Act 2 and the town in Act 3. It's also pretty aesthetically pleasing, and has a nice vibrant mood to it.

The only complaints I have are how long it takes for the game to load up sometimes, but that's probably because of my mediocre laptop. The story is a little negligible and none of the NPCs so far have really been memorable, but they're nice to have around anyways.

Overall, yes, you should try this game. It's free to play, so you've got nothing to lose by at least trying it out, but if you like other games like Torchlight or Diablo, then you'll definitely like this game too.

reviewText:
This game is an awsome hack'n'slash game , Free to play and not at all pay 2 win.

I spend numerous hours playing it before it launched on steam and still do , after around 2000 hours , I am still not bored.

All content is free for everyone , they add content , new areas , new items , new skills and spells all the time.

There are a lot of event and competetive races , ranging from short 12 minute burst races to 4 month long races where everyone competes against each other.

There are 4 modes in this game:

Standart: Just standart , you die you respawn , no big deal.
Hardcore: Basicly hardcore , you die and your character will be transfered to standart.
Standart League : a 4 month race with the standart rule.
Hardcore league : a 4 month race with the hardcore rule.

The short races are fun , and reward players with points that you get unique items for.
This items are obainable ingame via drops or trading other players , so you don't loose anything if you don't join them.
The point given in this races can't be bought with real money , so it is truly fair for everyone.

There are 7 classes in Path of Exile which all share the same passive skill tree [the skill tree has 1350 passive skills] , the only diffrence between the classes are how they look and where they start , in the passive tree.

TL:DR Download it now.
