reviewText:
This game is fantastic! It reminds a lot the gameplay of Diablo franchise, being a classic point & click action-RPG. If you're a fan of Diablo, you should definitely play it.
As a low point of the game, the history is not as enganging as Diablo was. I still remember the first time I played it, the felling of going down to Hell to kill Diablo itself kept me going on. Do not expect something that remarkable on Path of Exile.
The are some innovation on this game. The first is the fact that your potions replenish as you kill enemies. This saves you to keep returning to town to buy extra health/mana potions and make the game more dynamic. Also, you don't have money/gold in this game. The game currency are the items that you use to improve your weaponry/armory (as orbs or scrolls of identify). So, you need to decide between using the items to buy new weapons/armors or to improve the ones you already have.
In conclusion, this game is a must play for fans of hack and slash action-RPG, like myself. But being a free-to-play game, I recommend everybody to give it a try. I'm sure you're going to enjoy it.

reviewText:
Diablo 2 + FF7 Materia system.

Solid ARPG with a very fun early game full of experimentation and discovery, and a brilliant end game with great features. A lot of the space between can REALLY REALLY suck though, as you bottleneck your build at the gear level, needing very specific number, color, and connection schemes of slots, and needing those setups on items with decent stats as well.

Highly recommended for the most hardcore, and the most casual. Normal players may find themselves bored and leaving in the mid game, or playing a large number of characters and fighting with stash space.

reviewText: To start: this game is probably one of the best structured free to play games simply because the extent of the cash shop outside of cosmetic items is extra shared stash tabs (which you might need more tabs later on, but with a bit of organization it's usually not too bad). The way the skill system works allows for some nice builds, with a slotting and linking system not too different from Final Fantasy 7, like if you have a spell that shoots a fireball, you can put that gem in a socket in your armor and have it linked to a gem that makes it a spell totem and allows you to summon a totem that shoots fireballs. Keeping on with the Final Fantasy comparisons, the Passive tree is huge, with each class starting off in different areas of it, sort of similar to how Final Fantasy 10 was like and each point making a decent difference, and there is the choice of respeccing, but it's a bit tough to do (it partially requires a currency item for large respecs, you get respec points for some quests throughout the game but for anything more than 10 points it requires this currency item).\n\nA very unique aspect about the game as well is that it has no gold or equivalent, rather there are Currency Items" that all have different uses like a scroll that identifies items
date: an orb that creates a rare from a normal weapon
recommended: and even an extremely rare item that can clone an item. All of these types of items take the place of gold and it works fairly well for the most part except for when trying to first start player trading
hoursPlayed: as it's a bit hard to learn the rates of all the items if you're hard pressed to get a certain item/currency.\n\nAs for the gameplay
voteText: it feels good
helpfulPercent: especially with critical hits where if certain elements crit
votesHelpful: they'll have a different effect
votesTotal: like if an Ice spell crits the enemies that get hit by it are frozen. There are also different leagues that change up how the game itself works
votesFunny: and even race leagues that are only open for usually an hour and earns you "Season Points" for collecting and getting alternate artwork uniques in game. It plays really well with certain builds getting ludicrously fast paced later on or if you want to take your time there are builds for that too
commentsCount: the game is very flexible when it comes to available builds but that has a problem for me: Desync. Since this game is online only it is always correcting itself to the server
column16: and it's fairly common to end up getting warped to a different area that you were earlier because the server didn't think you were actually able to walk somewhere when you could (for example you got surrounded but were able to get out of it
column17: sometimes the server will warp you back into it because it thought the tiny opening you walked out of was closed.) For the impact this has on builds is simple: some builds just aren't viable because of the danger of being placed into an area you didn't want to go
column18: and not to mention some skills just plain desync more often than others because of being movement skills/spells.\n\nIn short: The game is pretty much perfect in my opinion except for desync
column19: which is a very large issue that can really kill any enjoyment I'm having no matter where I'm at in the game if it happens in a fatal way.\n\nScore: 4/5"

reviewText:
Poor man's (free to play) Diablo. The gem/skill system is interesting, which is reminicent of Final Fantasy 7's materia system. The graphics are decent enough and there's plenty of loot to be had and depth in combining skills by linking slots together (ala support materia in FF7). However...

The always-online aspect of this game is not so great, though. Rubberbanding is fairly consistent, even with a low ping. The game itself is the gatekeeper for your fun, dictating how viable you are by not only gear drops, but what skills you have access to. The time-sink basis of the game is a bit of a turn off. Expect to carefully plan a character and have it nerfed to bejesus, thereby ending your character as many have been so vocal about online, since resetting a character's skills is basically impossible. The currency system favors NPCs at every level, and the loot system is a free-for-all grabfest, so play with people you trust.

If you play this game, play with a group. Play with friends. Solo I can imagine is a nightmare considering how tempermental drops can be, but crushing things in a group and splitting loot means there's fun times for those seeking them.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic! It reminds a lot the gameplay of Diablo franchise, being a classic point & click action-RPG. If you're a fan of Diablo, you should definitely play it.
As a low point of the game, the history is not as enganging as Diablo was. I still remember the first time I played it, the felling of going down to Hell to kill Diablo itself kept me going on. Do not expect something that remarkable on Path of Exile.
The are some innovation on this game. The first is the fact that your potions replenish as you kill enemies. This saves you to keep returning to town to buy extra health/mana potions and make the game more dynamic. Also, you don't have money/gold in this game. The game currency are the items that you use to improve your weaponry/armory (as orbs or scrolls of identify). So, you need to decide between using the items to buy new weapons/armors or to improve the ones you already have.
In conclusion, this game is a must play for fans of hack and slash action-RPG, like myself. But being a free-to-play game, I recommend everybody to give it a try. I'm sure you're going to enjoy it.

reviewText:
Nostolgia bait. Take the gameplay, gritty tones and extreme gore of Diablo 1 & 2, add a more fully realized materia system from Final Fantasy 7, and a difficulty curve that makes getting to max level an actual acheivment, like the good old days. This game is old school, and anyone who grew up playing video games in the 90's is probably going to love it.

The only negative that I can find, is a social chat that lowers your IQ at best, and makes you want to put the live end of a power cord in your mouth at worst. The community comes off as a preteen sausagefest that dosn't know how to communicate ideas outside of internet memes.

GET OFF MY LAWN

reviewText:
After 2,000 hours of playing this game, I still can't get enough. GGG has to be one of the best, if not the best game developers out there. They've done such a great job with this game.

If you like grinding games for better loot, this is for you. If you're new to this genre, you're gonna have to take some time to fully understand the concepts of the game. It's definitely a lot to take in as a new player, but once you've figured it out it becomes so addicting.

There's new leagaues implemeneted every 3-4 months, which allows for fresh economies/new aspects to the game. It's my favorite part.

The devs are constantly updating/rebalancing the passive tree (which is freaking amazing), so you shouldn't get to in love with any given play style/skill/build. If you're new, definitely follow some of the big streamers so you can stay up to date on decent builds to use for new leagues.

There's tons more I can say, but I'll leave it here. Download poe, and have fun grinding!

reviewText:
PoE is everything Diablo 3 should have been. But nothing more.

PoE embodies the addictive hack and slay clickfest experience we have enjoyed since Diablo,
but comes with a completely open, intelligently designed map of passive skills, combinable active skill gems, all wrapped
in up to date graphics and an epic, immersive soundtrack. PoE combines all the good stuff we know with some new ideas,
including:

- Active skills can not be learned but are used as gems you put into socketed items.
- There is no gold. Instead, there is a number of useful currency items in the game's purely trade based item sink shops.
- Although the game is free to play and comes with an ingame shop, it's clearly not pay to win. The shop only offers a variety of vanity items and slots for characters and storage space.

It's a fun game, but it's very genre-typical and after a few hours of monster grinding you might come to realize that you're just not 14 anymore and that as you matured hack and slay, or action RPG" as it is generally euphemized
date: might not exactly be the most stimulating experience for you anymore. However
hoursPlayed: it does masterfully. The vortex of "I need +10 dex to be able to use this an that....." and "let's just keep going until 4am or to the next waypoint..." while playing with friends
voteText:
tends to remind of old D2 times.

It's nothing less than the best hack and slay I have seen since D2. But noting more either.
"

reviewText:
PROS:
- Spiritual successor of Diablo II (visuals/art style, atmosphere, UI, level design, and so on.)
- Perfect free-to-play scheme with zero pay-to-win elements (real money can be used to purchase cosmetic items only.)
- Unique and interesting skill tree.
- Loots

CONS:
- Unfriendly for casuals (inevitable rerolls due to complicated and unforgiving min/max builds.)
- Obnoxiously frequent desync/lag issues.
- Production value.

Final Remarks:
All H&S and ARPG fans should take a look at Path of Exile.

. RECOMMENDED .

reviewText: To start: this game is probably one of the best structured free to play games simply because the extent of the cash shop outside of cosmetic items is extra shared stash tabs (which you might need more tabs later on, but with a bit of organization it's usually not too bad). The way the skill system works allows for some nice builds, with a slotting and linking system not too different from Final Fantasy 7, like if you have a spell that shoots a fireball, you can put that gem in a socket in your armor and have it linked to a gem that makes it a spell totem and allows you to summon a totem that shoots fireballs. Keeping on with the Final Fantasy comparisons, the Passive tree is huge, with each class starting off in different areas of it, sort of similar to how Final Fantasy 10 was like and each point making a decent difference, and there is the choice of respeccing, but it's a bit tough to do (it partially requires a currency item for large respecs, you get respec points for some quests throughout the game but for anything more than 10 points it requires this currency item).\n\nA very unique aspect about the game as well is that it has no gold or equivalent, rather there are Currency Items" that all have different uses like a scroll that identifies items
date: an orb that creates a rare from a normal weapon
recommended: and even an extremely rare item that can clone an item. All of these types of items take the place of gold and it works fairly well for the most part except for when trying to first start player trading
hoursPlayed: as it's a bit hard to learn the rates of all the items if you're hard pressed to get a certain item/currency.\n\nAs for the gameplay
voteText: it feels good
helpfulPercent: especially with critical hits where if certain elements crit
votesHelpful: they'll have a different effect
votesTotal: like if an Ice spell crits the enemies that get hit by it are frozen. There are also different leagues that change up how the game itself works
votesFunny: and even race leagues that are only open for usually an hour and earns you "Season Points" for collecting and getting alternate artwork uniques in game. It plays really well with certain builds getting ludicrously fast paced later on or if you want to take your time there are builds for that too
commentsCount: the game is very flexible when it comes to available builds but that has a problem for me: Desync. Since this game is online only it is always correcting itself to the server
column16: and it's fairly common to end up getting warped to a different area that you were earlier because the server didn't think you were actually able to walk somewhere when you could (for example you got surrounded but were able to get out of it
column17: sometimes the server will warp you back into it because it thought the tiny opening you walked out of was closed.) For the impact this has on builds is simple: some builds just aren't viable because of the danger of being placed into an area you didn't want to go
column18: and not to mention some skills just plain desync more often than others because of being movement skills/spells.\n\nIn short: The game is pretty much perfect in my opinion except for desync
column19: which is a very large issue that can really kill any enjoyment I'm having no matter where I'm at in the game if it happens in a fatal way.\n\nScore: 4/5"

reviewText:
Diablo 2 + FF7 Materia system.

Solid ARPG with a very fun early game full of experimentation and discovery, and a brilliant end game with great features. A lot of the space between can REALLY REALLY suck though, as you bottleneck your build at the gear level, needing very specific number, color, and connection schemes of slots, and needing those setups on items with decent stats as well.

Highly recommended for the most hardcore, and the most casual. Normal players may find themselves bored and leaving in the mid game, or playing a large number of characters and fighting with stash space.

reviewText: This is a game with some great ideas: the skill system is deep, many of the unique items are genuinely interesting and build-enabling, and the commodity currency system is an awesome feature in theory.  Unfortunately, high-variance RNG mechanics screw everything up in the endgame.  Item hunting, crafting, and even maintaining access to high end content are all punishing tasks without being skill-based, and at a certain point you'll have to ask yourself, Why am I doing this?"  I'd recommend playing until you hit that point

reviewText: This is the first game that satisfies all of my cravings to replay Diablo II. Do not let its Free to Play status scare you away. This feels like a full game right from the first second of gameplay and does not hide a single feature, item, or area behind a pay wall. I haven't looked through all of the games microtransaction options yet (which so far seem to be all cosmetic) because I have been too busy crushing hordes of enemies and customizing my character. It combines the itemization of Diablo II with the Materia system of Final Fantasy VII and the Sphere Grid of Final Fantasy X.\n\nIf you liked Diablo II or were disappointed by the mess that was Diablo III, I absolutely cannot recommend checking out this game enough.

reviewText:
Great Game, probably the best game i played so far.
I don't usually enjoy games that use instances, but the construction and the plot of the game is just amazing.

Standart D3 graphics and gameplay. But what got me going when playing the game was the plot of the game.
The quests are refreshing and chalenging and the map system is amazing.

The skill tree is just over the top, complex but simple at the same time. Giving that u have big nodes that u aim for, but still have lots of ways u can get there, therefor, u have a lot of build diversification.

Another thing that got me going was the irl money shop. The mtx's are incredible and extremelly well done, although the price is quite high its a great way to make a non P2W game.

I give the game a solid 10/10 and recommend the game to people that like grinding type games.

reviewText: Path of Exile is one of the best games I've ever played. PoE is a free to play game, but unlilke most other f2p games out there, there is absolutely no way to gain any bonuses or anything by paying money. The only thing you get by paying money is cool skins for your gear. It doesn't have have any effect on the actual gameplay. The game is quite complicated, but that is what keeps me coming back for more, as there is a near-infinite amount of combinations of skills and character builds, most of them with significantly different playstyles. While the campaign does get a little old after a while, (on one character, you have to repeat the campaign 3 times on different difficulties), Grinding Gear Games has said that they have more content in the works that will eliminate this, with a new act scheduled for release in early 2015. Overall, I would rate PoE 10/10, a must-play.

reviewText:
Great Game, probably the best game i played so far.
I don't usually enjoy games that use instances, but the construction and the plot of the game is just amazing.

Standart D3 graphics and gameplay. But what got me going when playing the game was the plot of the game.
The quests are refreshing and chalenging and the map system is amazing.

The skill tree is just over the top, complex but simple at the same time. Giving that u have big nodes that u aim for, but still have lots of ways u can get there, therefor, u have a lot of build diversification.

Another thing that got me going was the irl money shop. The mtx's are incredible and extremelly well done, although the price is quite high its a great way to make a non P2W game.

I give the game a solid 10/10 and recommend the game to people that like grinding type games.

reviewText:
After 2,000 hours of playing this game, I still can't get enough. GGG has to be one of the best, if not the best game developers out there. They've done such a great job with this game.

If you like grinding games for better loot, this is for you. If you're new to this genre, you're gonna have to take some time to fully understand the concepts of the game. It's definitely a lot to take in as a new player, but once you've figured it out it becomes so addicting.

There's new leagaues implemeneted every 3-4 months, which allows for fresh economies/new aspects to the game. It's my favorite part.

The devs are constantly updating/rebalancing the passive tree (which is freaking amazing), so you shouldn't get to in love with any given play style/skill/build. If you're new, definitely follow some of the big streamers so you can stay up to date on decent builds to use for new leagues.

There's tons more I can say, but I'll leave it here. Download poe, and have fun grinding!

reviewText: This game is just...everything I want in a Diablo styled Action RPG.  The unique skill gem system, the amazing stat tree, everything is just so well put together.  The tree is so large that almost every character in the game is unique, and there are what seems like an endless amount of combinations.  The support gems are also nice.  For example, the Spark gem with a fork support gem would cause the spark to split off into 3 directions.  Or the Life Leech support, which leeches life on a hit as long as you use the supported skill.  The loot system is also fantastic.  Unique items are difficult, yet not impossible to find, and if you find something good for a different character, you can just stash it for them.  All in all, it's a very unique game and many things it does, it does well.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me start of with the most important point: Path of Exile is the absolute best implementation of F2P I've experienced. I am not hesitant to try free-to-play games out, but I am very wary of pay-to-win or ♥♥♥♥ game design caused by a game being F2P. Not once have I felt like any pay-cash-for-me items were being pushed in my face. I'm currently playing through the third and final difficulty, and the game being F2P hasn't gotten in the way of it a single time. While the game is not without its flaws, it is silly to avoid it trying since the financial barrier to entry is $0.

With dungeon crawlers there are a few core components that come to mind, that seem to make or break a given game. 1) Replayability 2) Mechanics 3) Skill trees 4) Item dropping/randomization. I will try to briefly talk about each of these issues.

In terms of replayability, Path of Exile is fantastic. I got bored of Titan Quest, Torchlight, and Diablo 3 much faster than I have in PoE. I actually hated Titan Quest by the time I finished it, I was just determined to beat it. Diablo 3 I quit during the final difficulty because they were still figuring out how to make the game suck less. Torchlight I just got disinterested in very quickly, although I plan to revisit it in the future.

The mechanics are probably the biggest selling point of the game in my opinion. Rarely does casting skills in a game make you feel like as much of a badass as it does in Path of Exile. The punch you get from using some of the skills is quite rewarding. While the gameplay is hampered a bit by lag now and then, by and large the game is very fast paced, and quite challenging at times.

The skill trees, gems, and leveling system really are a fantastic piece of game design. I won't try to explain how it works because it is worth exploring and learning yourself. While it isn't without its flaws, I really do love the adaptability the skill trees give you. My second character might not turn out as absolutely awesome as my first did, I feel like I kind of nailed it with my first build. Also, it's worth mentioning the currency system is downright clever.

The item dropping and randomization is probably the weak point of the entire game imo. While it isn't completely terrible, I can almost completely ignore loot that drops at this point in the game (~Lvl 55). Most things have such a low chance of comparing to what I already have, that it isn't worth looking. I still do, but it is usually futile. The need to get items with both good stats, AND appropriate gem sockets, is really the core problem. It is hard to hold this weakness against it, as this is something almost every dungeon crawler that exists fails at, especially Diablo 3.

The fact that this game is online-only hampers it in the same way it did for Diablo 3. There are definitely lag/sync issues that come up now and then. The ability to play in LAN mode, especially for something like hardcore mode (which I will never ever attempt), is almost essential. This is only a slight gripe, as I haven't even paid a cent for the game yet. I do plan on dumping some money into it at some point, primarily just to support the game/devs.

Overall, if you like dungeon crawlers, or even just trying solid free-to-play games, this is one is definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
Path of Exile is clearly a labour of love. It's a wonderful game with some fresh ideas and good mechanics that breaths some more life into the traditional ARPG format.

It is similar to Diablo 3, Torchlight 2 and Titan Quest in general gameplay. All your standard things such as levelling up, loot, random levels and monster slaying are here. Where it differs from the aforementioned games is the skill and level-up system, which is an interesting change. As you level up, you gain passive skill points to spend on things such as damage, armour, critical chance etc.

You gain your active skills from a variety of different gems, which can be freely plopped into items you find - and taken out without a fuss. This allows you to quickly swap skills in and out - completely changing your play-style in a matter of seconds. These gems also level-up with you and become more powerful. You can create powerful combos by linking support gems with active skills to augment your favourites.

This balance between permanent" passive skills and changeable active skills is actually really good and works well together. You can still build a character to exactly what you want - and the passive skill "tree" is absolutely huge.

Different classes start the game at different points in the skill tree
date: meaning they can gain access to abilities that suit them best earlier than other classes
hoursPlayed: with a bit of work
voteText: you can turn pretty much any class in the game to do something different. It's unique and very well rounded.\n\nAs a free-to-play game

reviewText:
You probably thought this would be another pros and cons review. You were right, but let me first tell you some general things and I will end with my opinion at the end of the review.

PoE is a hack and slash ARPG that has an incredible amount of depth. It has so much depth that it was the main reason for me to switch from Diablo 3 to PoE. Apart from the many, many uniques there is a huge passive tree, so extensive that it gives you nearly endless possibilites to customise and direct your character build. It is responsive in terms of casting abilites, skills, attacking, moving, etc, much like Diablo 3. The graphics are simple-ish but ok in my opinion, the game uses less bright colors compared to diablo 3 and is less prone to giving you epileptic seizures.

Let's first get rid of the cons:
-inconcsistent FPS --> really demanding game in terms of requirements, it will run smoothly and then some cluster♥♥♥♥ of spells and abilities will produce an fps drop (maybe it's just me though, but I think I have a pretty good pc)
-server crashes and bugs sometimes appear, altough it's not that often to really undermine the game. It's rare but it's there
-if you are playing on an EU server it is possible to enter groups with NA players (for example) that will switch you to their server and consequently increase your ping to ~500ping
-the start of the game is really slow, meaning that you will not have that start as in Diablo 3 for example where you start hacking and slashing furiously at lvl1, PoE requires higher attack speed/cast speed to achieve that level of speed/responsivnes. Meaning you will have the fast game in the late game.
-it's a grinding game

Now for the pros:
-free to play (not pay to win, don't worry, all microtransactions are merely cosmetic apart from the stash extentions)
-huge depth: a really high number of different builds that are all viable in some way and customisation of everything (from your gear and hideouts to the maps that you will be tackling on in late game)
-responsivnes
-large amount of late game content
-races where you can earn unique gear rewards
-fun leagues with unique rules that last for 3 months each: new economy, fresh start and rewards
-permanent leagues
-it's hard as ♥♥♥♥ to reach lvl100
-it's a grinding game

All in all I recommend this game. Why? Because you have stuff to do. Yes it's grindy but at least you have the satisfactory soul fulfiling skills/abillities that destroy enemies to your hearts content in many more ways than one. My point is you will never get bored because you can always make a unique build that you will enjoy. A build tailored for you, by you, not by external sites. My only recommendation is that you plan and learn in advance. Well, those are my main reasons why I switched to this game. It's excellent, really and I would recommend you try it, after all, it's free to play. I'd rate this game 8.5/10.

reviewText: I don't think I've ever been so consumed by a game than I have by Path of Exile. This is a great ARPG with fast-pased combat and lots and lots of variety in playstyles, not to mention the massive passive skill tree! The endgame is near to endless and the devs are constantly adding new exciting content! It's about gathering knowledge and effectively using that knowledge to your advantage! Great game, great dev team, who also listen to their consumers.\n\nI think my playtime here speaks for itself.

reviewText:
Path of Exile has been almost nonstop fun since I picked it up in closed beta at the end of 2011. I've put in hundreds of hours over many characters before this game hit Steam. If you like Diablo, you will likely enjoy PoE. This is the spiritual successor to Diablo 2.  Prepare yourself though - this isn't as simple as Diablo 3, and requires a lot more planning, thought, and testing to have an effective build.

Math of Exile is a game where you afk in town while reading up on skill mechanics and planning out how you're going to set up your future passive skill points. The mechanics of combat, damage, and character resources (health, mana, energy shield, armor, etc) are very well thought out and make for strong ARPG combat, as a spiritual successor to the Diablo line should be. Early game (the first ~19 levels) has a little more variety than D3 per character, but after level 19 your character will be able to use a much wider variety of skills, provided you can get them from a Master or another player, or find them as drops. Gameplay is varied, but approaching late game becomes a grind not unlike running GRs over and over. I personally find PoE's grind more fun because there's more I can do while grinding, and there's a large, active community in each league, and I can chat and get responses and conversations at any time.

Overall it's a modern Diablo 2 experience, with a more emphasis on grinding in the late game than D2, but in each respect is more rewarding than D3's more fun less gameplay" twist on the Diablo recipe.

You will be tested
date: and you will be found wanting. Just try to survive."

reviewText:
Path of Legends is another great indie game to add to EA's records of acheivement. You start of with a selection from various characters, these include lulu the dark witch, taric the holy one, and lastly master yi the forgoten avanger. I myself played as yi and the story is great although it does have a few plot holes here and there. In any case you find yourself on a beach after the summer cruise ship you were on got assaulted by the deadswamp pirates. Yi was engaged to be married and had all of his family onboard the cruise at the time. unfortunately the pirates were ruthless and slayed every man woman and child. Yi tried to resist but was overpowerd by a surge of lightening on the stormy night that accompanied the deadswamp pirate assault. Amongst the wreckage of the ship he eventually floated to the island in which you start the game. Theres nothing much to it at first, you are lying face planted in the dirt. You learn to survive as you craft with various tools. Immersion breaks here because you cut down trees with your bare hands, but i suppose this could be attributed to Yi being a badass and so it can be justified.

Eventually you can build yourself a nice hut, and after you do some rather grindy farming you can establish a good forward outpost. You get promted mid game to purchase station cash from the soney online entertainment website to speed things up, but i never was a fan of DLC so i dont support EA's decision to monetise indie games like this. After you build the foward outpost you get to fight the first boss, a giant enemy crab which is symbolic of Yi's personal struggles from his japanese heritage. the crab is symbolic of real historical battles in ancient china and for the little historian in all of us i found this quite compelling as a plot twist. beating the crab allows you to advance to the next section, where you meet rico from just cause 2.

Rico gives you the grappleing hook as he too was on the cruise ship but took a bullet to the hip and just cant do what he did in the previous game. Fortunately for us, Yi gets to swing around the area pretty quickly. the hook allows you to make it to the central island, where the plot thickens once Yi discovers theres an american military base centred in the area that has been testing equipment. Yi appraoches the base in a freindly manner, but is instantly gunned down and escapes within an inch of his life. The game turns toward gurrilla warfare fromt his point on. You need to take out key military instillations over the island (such as propaganda stations and fuel depots) to try and win over the local populus. Once youve garnered enough strength you can take the military hq head on to liberate panaoa from the terrorist organisation that has rooted itself in the heart of the island.

THe final stages of the game involve strolling the halls of the HQ, which span deep underground. Yi uncovers the secrets this place holds. the organisation were responsible for the pirate attack on the ship, hired mercinaries trying to obtain a rare artifact being transported on the cruise that nobody knew about. This clearly explaines why rico was onboard and this was certainly no ordinary cruise. The artifact was being used to reanimate flesh to create necromongers to satisfy some weird cult called zoology established by Tom ultman. From this point on Yi knew what he had to do and where he needed to go... space... THe game ends with Yi having a choise to destroy the evil facility, or instead render it inert for future research by the alliance which hope to harness this power against the bretheren moons. Once you make your choice you can hitch  a ride on the ebon normandy, a test vehicle in the hanger which is fully developed and primed for space flight. YOu can take with you some local aquaintances you met on the island, or just go solo. In any case, you leave the island and make your way to eden prime, and this is the basis for the second installment of league of exiles which we here at indieholic ardently await to get our greasy little hands on.

until next time, stay snazzy gamerz!
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: What the hell Blizzard? A F2P indie game is better than the multimillion dollar disaster that was Diablo 3? I'm not sure how to rate this because IMO it's far better than any of its competition, and it's FREE. While I'm still not a big fan of these types of games and can never seem to get addicted, I don't really know what to complain about. The cash shop is all cosmetic crap. The multiplayer runs decently and is simple to play with friends. The combat is much better than Torchlight 2's IMO. It's not a huge change from the old dungeon crawler loot genre, but I'll be damned if it's not a great game that's FREE and can be played solo. As someone who isn't a fan of this genre I want to give it an 8/10. As someone who has seen all the trash that HAS been released in this genre lately, I got to go with 10/10. If you like this type of game, give this a go.

reviewText:
Diablo III done right. Wayyyy more class customization, wayyyy more class options, custom spells, customizable weapons. What more could you want? The leveling system is similar to final Fantasty XIII, in which you get points and rank up different stats in a web. Not to mention the web has over 1,000 different options to choose from. Incredibly enjoyable to play with your best friends. There is infinite replayability. The levels randomly regenerate when you revisit them and the graphics are incredibly detailed. So much enjoyment was felt whilst playing this game.

Diablo III done right.... and did I mention that it's free?

10/10

With the launch of this game just emerging on steam, the sky is the limit with how much potential this game has.

Imagine Diablo 2 + Materia system from FFVII + Skill tree from Witcher 2 (20x bigger).

Now add Ironman difficulty and no gold. (The game is based on a commodity system, Item A for Item B)

reviewText:
Diablo fans rejoice!  Path of Exile is without a doubt the prodigal successor to a franchise that's getting harder to innovate and draw people in every year.  PoE just nails it, all of it!  From the gothic art style and the mood defining music to the near endless list of innovations that make this game so great and really set it apart in an extremely positive way from any other action RPG.  If you haven't gotten yourself lost in Wraeclast, do yourself a favor and install this game immediately.

Some of the highlights with this game

- Nearly limitless amount of itemization
- Really unique mana/health replenishment system (Flasks that refill and have special properties)
- Huge amount of skill combinations involving gems that can be linked in nearly limitless ways
- A passive skill tree that has millions (yes millions!) of different useful and interesting combos
- Huge community that is backed by a passionate developer team that even today continues to support and improve gameplay
- Excellent endgame that is still being developed (maps, hideouts, etc.)
- 6 player co-op
- Leagues and race events that can earn you prizes
- hundreds and hundred of useful uniques that change the way you play in a variety of ways

...and the list goes on!

reviewText:
Now the devs finally have fixed desynch issues, I can finally recommend this game to everyone. Its not only the best dungeon crawler RPG I've played. But it got the greatest skill tweaking I've ever seen. It got the biggest passive skilltree I've seen in a game to date, and if a skilltree is not enough for you to define your character: Well PoE has skill gems to add abilities to your character, which can be linked by support gems to enhance them. You can also add certain kind of gems to some slots in your skilltree, for even more character building.

Some people claim this to be a better Diablo then Diablo 3". I can't tell since I've never played Diablo :/ All I know that this game is great and has the best F2P strategy then 90% of other F2P games.

The only complaint I got is that you get barrely enough stashtabs to play
date: and you have to buy more with $$$."

reviewText: So, after almost 1,300 hours im writing a review, i've played many ARPG games in the past, starting from Diablo 2, to torchlight 2, and diablo 3, but none of them was as near as fun as Path of Exile, when i tried Diablo 3 I played only 20 minutes and got bored, went back to Path of Exile. This game is perfect in any way possible, the Performance is flawless (unless you cast on crit), after 2.0 deployed Desync is fixed, still back in 1.3 it was fun to R.I.P to some desync, the endless build choices is the thing that stands out for me, you literally have no limits. I also love the fact that is completely free, you cant be better than someone, just because you've put more money in PoE. So i'd give it 10/10, no doubt, i will play it untill im dead or something, not stopping soon. ;) Thanks GGG for taking my life :( <3

reviewText:
I truly consider this the great sequel to Diablo II . Being free-to-play is even greater ( but DO NOT compare this game with Diablo III, for they are different games. Diablo III is a game in its own right, it deserves the attention for it is very polished and well conceived ).

Path of Exile has the exact style of Diablo II and although I don't agree with the spamming trade system, complicated class skill tree and inability to re-roll skill points easily, I do praise the developers for starting the game and continuing Diablo II's dark legacy in a different lore and graphic engine.

Deserves a 10/10 from a Diablo fan like myself.

reviewText:
If you like gear based grinding games then this one is for you.

Let me start out by saying that I enjoy a hard challenge and have to play on hardcore, where you only die once and then you drop down to standard mode (softcore).  Any character that drops down like this is dead to me, never to be played again.

I wasn't sold on this game at first as I got sick of dying at lot :) .  Lately been playing it a lot and more and now I understand the boss mechanics accept that I will die at some point but it's just a matter of how long I can last.

With a massive skill tree where you can spend 120 skill points from 1350 skill nodes there is a large amount of replayability.  Even though there is a lot of repetition in replaying the same maps over and over (until you beat Merciless difficulty and move into endgame randomised maps") it's the character customisation that keeps me coming back.

Give it a shot

reviewText:
At the time of the review I have about 700 hours logged on steam version.
Path of Exile is  a hardcore action RPG with a lot of depth. It will most likely take a while to get in to and it is not suited for quite a lot of gamers. However, this game is absolutely fantastic.

Pros and cons can be subjective, so I'll just point out main points.
-Hardcore. Can be a heaven for hardcore gamers and a nightmare for casuals. Not recommended for your first ARPG.

-Free-to-play but not pay-to-win. GGG's microtransaction system is very fair. Almost everything is cosmetics and nothing in microtransaction store gives anyone an advantage.

-Realistic gritty graphics. I personally love the graphic and art style, but it is highly subjective.

-Music varies from meh" to absolute blasts. From boring lullabies to beautiful symphonies.

-Sound design is pretty solid. Good voice acting and realistic sounds.

-Support is great and quick. I personally had great time using it.

-Game has classes
recommended:
the class only changes how your character looks and from where he/she starts from the skill tree.

-Characters can use any skills or items if they have required stats. Skills are skill gems that can be socketed in to items.

-Ridiculously flexible and huge skill tree. You can make thousands or possibly even millions of builds with the tree provided. Skill tree consists of little upgrades (For example
hoursPlayed: 0.3% life regeneration or 12% more physical damage.)Some people don't like this
voteText: but those small upgrades stack fast
helpfulPercent: I personally love the freedom of the skill tree.\n\n-Game is based on leagues
votesHelpful: so there will be different leagues where you can create a new character and try new things.\n\n-Lot of equipment variance
votesTotal: you can find
votesFunny:
buy or craft items perfect for your build or even multiple ones.

-Trading is decent but should be worked on. You either need to yell to chat or use 3rd party websites to make trades. Game has no auction houses or player shops in-game.

-Leveling can be quick or slow
commentsCount: depending on build and skill. Max level is 100 and you can reach level 70 in 10-15 hours.\n\n-The game has 3 difficulties
column16: Normal
column17: Cruel and Merciless. You will move to the next difficulty after completing storyline. Story currently is composed of 3 acts (4th one is coming soon) and you complete those acts in each difficulty. This can be very boring
column18: since it can feel like the game is repeating.\n\n-The endgame is a map system. You can craft mods in to your maps to make them fit your build or your needs. I personally love this system
column19: since it offers a lot of variance
column20: varying difficulties and different experiences.\n\n-The D-sync (Should be fixed in the Awakening expansion). Basically
column21: you will be off sync from the game and you might in a different position than your character seems to be on your screen. This can and probably will cause a lot of deaths and frustration
column22:
but should be getting fixed soon. (Only thing that has really caused me frustration in the game. Glad to see it going)

I might have forgotten some main points...
Overall
column23: I think Path of Exile is a fantastic game by a fantastic company and I recommend it whole heartedly."

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying this is a fantastic ARPG.  I love the classes, the items, the spells, the customization with the passive skill tree, the viability of many builds.  I love this game.  But this game suffers from a fundamental, glaring, insulting and infuriating flaw (well, flaws, but more about that later).

It desyncs constantly.  This may not be a big deal in early levels when mobs are fairly easy and the named/elite champs you fight aren't rocking proximity shields and damage reflection.  But when you're 60+, dealing with a room full of mobs that can literally 2-shot you if they get too close, it's borderline unplayable.  The difficulty factor would be perfect (probably a little too easy for archers) if it wasn't for these sneaky ninja-mobs that just show up and beat the living hell out of you.

Another flaw (imo) is the gem system.  In games like Diablo, gems/runes are used to augment abilities or add buffs/bonuses.  In PoE, however, gems are both your skills and your buffs/augments.  On my 61 Ranger I have maybe 13 gems, 6 of which are skills and 3 of which are buffs.  That leaves me with 4 or 5 support gems, not a big deal.  The problem is that in order to upgrade a piece of equipment, I have to find one that is an ilvl upgrade, has a specific number of sockets in specific colors and in a specifically-linked configuration, is a rare or better, and has to have good modifiers.  The alternative is finding a random piece of equipment and burning mats to change the number/color/linkage/quality/attributes/bonuses.  This makes the game feel like a grind-fest.   And even then, I'd forgive this aspect if I didn't constantly desync.

I want to love this game.  I've spent quite a lot of time playing, but I simply cannot play it anymore.  The desync issue is out of control, and absolutely breaks this game.

This is a complete head-scratcher.  It's been around too long to not have a succesful business model, but I'm astonished at how ethical the microtransactions are in this F2P Diablo-alike.

No, no hyperbole, I'm truly astonished.  I mean, it's almost hard to find the microtransactions, and they come in three flavors: Extra character slots, extra equipment tabs, and cosmetic appearances.

I don't know how many character slots PoE has, because playing one character is dozens of hours of playtime.  Playing two (it's nice to have a solo" character and a "co-op" character

reviewText:
Their Customer support is probably the worst you've experienced in any game.  My email address that I used to register the game can no longer receive mail.  To change my email address I had to first provide them with...

- The account name, date, time and location the account was created
- The IP address you created the account from, or if this is not possible, the IP address you last played from

... odd requests to begin with for an email address change.  I was actually able to provide these things...

Follow-up

- Can you please let us know whether you have made any purchases on the account from the online store.

I have not...

Follow-up


- Could you please create a throwaway account (preferably using another email address), create a character on it and start the first level, then provide us with the account name or email address that you used?

- Could you also please send us your client.txt file? It can be found under the Path of Exile\logs directory, and you may have to .zip it as it can be quite large.

I could not perform this request without downloading a non-steam version.  Continuing to play this game was not worth this effort to me.  I believe they were starting to send me on a run around as I have not purchased anything from them.



--- As for the game in General

Pros:

The game was generally fun.

The talent tree is huge, and allows for super customization, which may actually be a con for any casual player.

Cons:
The graphics are not great by any means.

You cant tab out and back in while in fullscreen mode without the game crashing, as far as I know that has been an issue for years.  Here is a thread from 2013...

https://www.pathofexile.com/forum/view-thread/654101

You can eventually reach a Hard stop where you character cannot progress any further.  This does not seem to be as much of an issue in rival games like Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2.  In addition to this, there is no good respec option if you surpass a certain level.  You can only back out one point at a time with a rather rare item drop.

reviewText: This is a fun Diablo 2 type game, however, every 4-6 months Grinding Gear Games patches the game so utterly that three times in 1.5 years all of my character classes were botched or totally ruined. For those who have played games like these, leveling up is the easy part...buying gear for the class of character is not. So when my 5 characters hit level 90 finally, GGG actually came out with their new Act 4 expansion which completely ruined each one of my characters to such a high degree that I needed to redo their entire play style...which made all that gear I spent months buying obsolete. This is definitely a game to stay away from. So much fun, free, sociable and simple but the absurb time needed for leveling and gear make it impossible to enjoy knowing that all of your hard work and god-seeki-ness will be undone in as small as a 5MB patch that alters the skill nodes!

reviewText:
As a Beta backer, I'm very happy with what GGG have done with this game over the years, Well polished and a really great replacement for Diablo 2.

When you start, it can be a bit daunting to look at that huge passive tree before you, but after a time it becomes easier and easier to travel around the tree. Look at guides online, it's completely fine too, see what you can do to tweek it, your first build will always be horrible if you do not get help, but when you do make that one magical build that destroys everything it's extremely rewarding.

The Currency in this game is what made me play it for so long, it's so complex but at the same time simple. The haggle game is real and it's so ALIVE, always moving, don't believe that one guy with the fixed prices because this game is ALL about Supply and Demand.

This game has no pants, does not matter, you still look like the dog's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ towards the endgame with full bodied armour huggin dem thighs tight.

Need more Help? Visit Path of Exiles forums, it's full of info. And use poe.xyz to buy stuff. it's a time saver. ;)

Addictive!

reviewText:
This is the game Diablo 3 should have been.  If you enjoyed the Diablo series, or are even curious about playing an Action Role-Playing Game (ARPG), definitely give this a try.

It's Free to Play, and don't let that dissuade you as some cheesy pay-to-win or trial scenario.  You can absolutely experience the full game without paying a cent.  When I first started playing in the Beta, though, I definitely saw the value here and gave them some money (for some cool cosmetic and account-based benefits), and you probably will want to, as well!

Grinding Gear Games does a great job supporting the game.  Nearly every week there is a new patch or update.

This is without a doubt my favorite game release of 2013.  What have you got to lose?  Try it!

reviewText:
Amazing game. I'll try to keep it short and explain why.

As someone that didn't like Diablo 3 (sorry for the never-ending comparison) that much because of the pay-to-win, this game is amazing and fair on all fronts. Yes you can use micro-transactions, however these are not pay-to-win in ANY way.

It's completely free, the graphics are nice, gameplay is fluid, etc.
The community features some very friendly people, and raiding together is a ton of fun and easy to do.

Classes are genderlocked, but if you want to play a male ranger, you can just slap on a bow on another class and play him ranged, it doesn't matter that much.

If you like action-RPGs and dungeon-crawlers, you should get this game. Now.
Go get it right away.

reviewText:
What do you get when you cross-breed Final Fantasy VII's materia system with Diablo 2? You get Path of Exile, a game which demands a great deal of theorycrafting and immense build diversity the likes of which you will never see in many ARPGs.

Pros:
+ Free to play
+ No pay-to-win, all microtransactions are aesthetic.
+ Vast build diversity
+ All skills are available to use by any class
+ Helpful, active community
+ New take on currency and how it affects trading
+ Massive, comprehensive skill tree.
+ (Personal interest) Competant summoning and minion features

Cons:
- Always online
- Trade chat is poorly implemented
- Game has terrible problems with desync
- Standard league economy is horribly inflated
- Not for casual gaming, requires a great deal of time and effort to get to the real fun parts of the game

Pros explained:
The first thing that attracted me to this game the most was the summoning system. Diablo 2 had spoiled me rotten with the necromancer, nothing was more fun for me than running around with a large army of skeletons at my back, ready to charge forward to engage the enemy. Not many ARPGs can pull off a good summoning mechanic, but when they do, its always amazing. Path of Exile not only lets you raise hordes of zombies that fight until they die, but also allows you to summon skeletons that offer support and come in larger numbers. The best part of summoning, however, comes in the form of raising spectres. Imagine fighting a monster that is very proficient at wiping out your minions, and then turning that monster into your own minion to fight for you! And there's more, from summoning flaming skulls that bypass enemies and small obstacles to animating weapons to animating a full-blown suit of armor!

The next big feature I loved about this game is how they handle currency. Most games just give you basic currency like gold which you use to buy or sell things. Not in this game! Currency comes in the form of special orbs which also provide useful functions. One orb can be used to give you respecs to your passive tree for example, another can be used to turn a mundane (white) item into a rare quality item. There's lots of orbs and each orb is valued differently between each other based on rarity on usefulness. If you can find the 'mirror of kalandra', you've officially become a rich player, but good luck finding it!

There are no direct skills to speak of when leveling up, but they are passive improvements. When it comes to Path of Exile, it doesn't give you a skill tree, it gives you a passive skill jungle! Those who have played Final Fantasy X will know what I'm talking about. The passive skill tree is what allows for such an amazing build diversity. Its very complicating for new players, but thankfully the forum has many build guides you can use to teach you how to build yourself. I highly recommend you try and make your own build first to understand the passive skill tree before reading a build guide.

Ah, but the greatest feature of all about this game lies in the actual skills themselves. This game offers a myriad of abilities that are accessible to every player, so long as they can meet the stat requirements for them. Want to throw a fireball? Sure. How about raining fire on the enemy? Why not! Want to throw a spectral copy of your weapon at an enemy and watch it fly back to you? You can get it. The fun doesn't stop there, no. You can also augment your abilities with support gems to make them more powerful! Want to shoot more fireballs at once, or to make them split on impact? There's support gems for that! Want your arrows to bounce between multiple enemies or pierce right through them? That's possible. Want your melee attacks to attack multiple times in one cast, or to make your melee do AoE damage? You can do that. There's infinite possibilities when using skills, you just need to know what works best!

Cons explained:
However, this game does have some downsides you will have to deal with. The first and perhaps biggest issue this game suffers from is desync. For those who don't know what desync is, the simplest way to describe it is that the client isn't in sync with the server. For instance, you're trying to escape from some enemies in a hall and while you think you have escaped, you're still taking damage and when you die, you wind up back where the enemies were. Rubberbanding is the best way to describe desync and you will be experiencing this a lot. If you play on the hardcore leagues, its IMPORTANT that you play carefully and utilize the '/oos' command in chat to resync.

This game is also not friendly to the more casual of gamers. Between build diversity, a complicated skill tree and a heavily inflated economy in the parent standard and hardcore leagues, this game demands a great deal of time and effort be invest before the game gets any fun. If you're not prepared to really sink your teeth into this game and hang on for dear life, you might want to consider playing something else.

But hey, this game is free. Free, and without pay-to-win microtransactions. There are microtransactions in this game, but they are all cosmetic and designed purely to make your character stand out from the rest. There are also pets you can buy as a microtransaction, but they are also purely for visual appeal and will not give you an advantage to combat. You will never have to worry about other players buying their way to greatness, everyone is on even ground here!

I really suggest you give this game a try, especially if you were a fan of Diablo 2!

Helpful resources:

http://www.poe.xyz.is
This site is great if you're looking to find an item in the game that you need. The site pulls information from the trade forum on the official site and if it finds a match, it will list all the items that meet your criteria. Clicking the item's name will take you straight to the player's trade thread on the forum!

http://www.pathofexile.gamepedia.com
This is the wiki for Path of Exile. Everything you will ever need to know about the game can be found here. This site is very active and updates immediately when new content is released. If you ever need to know what certain skills do or what uniques do, this is the place to go.

reviewText:
Easily the best game of the genre. Easily amongst the greatest F2P models. Easily the most deep and creative ways to build your character. Easily a must-play for everyone.

Pros
- FANTASTIC free to play model. You get the entire game right off the bat. There's really no 'except' or 'but' to this, you seriously just straight up get the entirety of the game. All the things you can spend $ on are things such as cosmetics for your character, pets, decorative set pieces for your hideout, and other petty stuff along those lines.

- The game features perhaps the deepest way to create a character's build in video gaming history. You see, the game has a passives tree with over 1,000 nodes to invest in. The class you pick merely determines where in the tree you'll start. For example, The Duelist class starts on the bottom, where strength and dexterity meet.  Here is a picture [i.imgur.com] of the current passives tree. This massive tree combined with the strange way you mix skill gems with support gems to bend your spells to do exatecly what you want. For example, you can attach a fireball (skill gem) with Lesser Multiple Projectiles (a support gem). Now instead of 1 fireball, you now shoot 3. Or perhaps you want to summon a totem to shoot the fireballs for you? Or maybe your fireballs fork into two more fireballs when they hit an enemy. On top of that, unique" items in the game can bend the normal rules for your character
date:
to allow for even more creativity and possibilites present.

- Three month leagues with special rules or permanent leagues. A multitude of various races to start a character at level 1 and reach the furthest in the game in a certain time under certain rules running every day. Softcore or hardcore. There's a lot of variety present in the game which is sure to find your niche.

- Amazing developers deliver content on the regular. I took a break from the game (after about 1
recommended: 200 hours) for 3 months and when I came back there were 14 new support gems

voteText: a new master system

and more bugfixes/quality of life changes than I cared to read in one session.

Cons

reviewText:
If you like ARPGs and loved Diablo 2, but didn't like Torchlight, then this would definitely satisfy your need for a D2 style game. All active skills are based on resocketable gems, making you're character build your own, and the passive talent system is very reminscent of the sphere grid/tree/maze in FFX, which gives you even more lattitude in determining how you want to create your character over the long run.

Some downsides:

- Bit of a learning curve. You'll need to check a wiki to see how to get the most out of the merchants and how to use support gems).
- No character customization for appearance.

You really have nothing to lose by playing this game, so give it a few hours and get a feel for it.

reviewText: Path of Exile is undoubtedly one of the best free-to-play titles in recent years. If you're a fan of eerie & spine chilling, fantasy hack 'n' slash games where fighting huge mobs of ghastly creatures and ominous soldiers are the norm, Path of Exile is for you. As many have said already, this game has a very similar feel to the Diablo series and takes a large amount of influence from it (i.e. how the game is set into Acts and once you have completed them you can move onto harder difficulties), but also adds something of it's own into the mix such as having no currency in the game. Path of Exile is what Diablo 3 should have been and totally takes the cake between the two. The amount of content in the game is astounding and sometimes I can't believe that this game is free-to-play. Of course, you have your proverbial microtransactions but unlike other games, Path of Exile offers mostly non-competitive items for sale such as more character slots and guild options. Player vs. Player is another great element to the game and from what I have seen it contains 1 vs 1, 3 vs 3 and 6 vs 6 arenas though the matchmaking is a bit buggy when joining a queue. So, if you are looking for an overly addicting, loot driven, online hack 'n' slash game with tons of gore and brutality, download this game now! You won't regret it!

reviewText:
Awesome game. Feels like the true successor to Diablo 2, as it still has a massive amount of customization you can do to a character (unlike Diablo 3's kid-friendly stat system).

The skill system is ripped straight from Final Fantasy VII's Materia system. Your skills are slotted into your gear and can only be used if they are slotted. I think it's a fantastic use of the system that works great in an ARPG. This increases the customization because any class can use any skill, assuming you have the stats to back it up. It allows for some crazy cross-class builds.

Combine that with the MASSIVE passive skill tree (Google it and see for yourself) and you'll be theorycrafting your perfect build for a long, long time.

To top it off, the microtransactions are purely aesthetic, so the game is not even remotely pay to win or pay to get epic loot quick. You still have to earn your gear, levels, and skills.

This is the perfect successor to Diablo 2.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
+Addictive ARPG Gameplay
+Multiple Character Options
+Coherent ARPG Story
+Free-To-Play without the Freemium

-Pacing drags towards the end

Path of Exile is the best Free-to-Play game on the PC market.  The monetization of the game is never shoved into your face and the game never feels like it is giving you a lesser experience for playing without spending.

The Action Role Playing Game (ARPG) elements are excelent as the various special abilities express variabilty in game mechanics while providing satisfying feedback in the form of crunchy-gory slaughter.  While there is plenty of good enemy variability throughout the campaign, your primary tactics will most likely not vary until you come accross large groups of enemies or platoons that mix range and melee combatants.

The character customization is limited to the items you wear and the sprawling skill tree that makes up the leveling system for the game.  While skill gems provide the meat of experience in terms of move sets, the skill tree simply determines what weapons and armor you can equip while providing percentage bonus to your damage and attack speeds.

All character classes are viable, however, it is important to note their specialties to best equip and advance your character for optimal slaying.  While the game is not necessarily difficult, deaths become common when you make haphazard or impatient mistakes to bring the fight to a large group of enemies.  Boss encounters can seem daunting at first, however, once you understand to eliminate their followers and then carefully avoid their primary attack, the fights become very manageable.

Path of Exile introduces some innovations or rather differing mechanics for bartering and potion use.  When you trade an item into a vendor, you recieve peices of identifying scrolls or alchemy gems that can be used to identify or make magic items respectively.  This displaces the importance of accumulated wealth into a more free form experimentation with getting better gear as you can often make a better item from a non-magical item and a few alchemy gems.  Potions are recharged from slaying enemies rather than consumed on an individual basis, which adjusts your tactics as you become heavily damaged.

Overall, I think Path of Exile is a great game, free-to-play or not.  I found it more engaging than Diablo III and Torchlight II, however, your experience might vary based on how the art style and story appeals to your tastes.  The game, though, is just fun and should be at least tried.

[GET ASAP]

reviewText:
Awesome game. Feels like the true successor to Diablo 2, as it still has a massive amount of customization you can do to a character (unlike Diablo 3's kid-friendly stat system).

The skill system is ripped straight from Final Fantasy VII's Materia system. Your skills are slotted into your gear and can only be used if they are slotted. I think it's a fantastic use of the system that works great in an ARPG. This increases the customization because any class can use any skill, assuming you have the stats to back it up. It allows for some crazy cross-class builds.

Combine that with the MASSIVE passive skill tree (Google it and see for yourself) and you'll be theorycrafting your perfect build for a long, long time.

To top it off, the microtransactions are purely aesthetic, so the game is not even remotely pay to win or pay to get epic loot quick. You still have to earn your gear, levels, and skills.

This is the perfect successor to Diablo 2.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
+Addictive ARPG Gameplay
+Multiple Character Options
+Coherent ARPG Story
+Free-To-Play without the Freemium

-Pacing drags towards the end

Path of Exile is the best Free-to-Play game on the PC market.  The monetization of the game is never shoved into your face and the game never feels like it is giving you a lesser experience for playing without spending.

The Action Role Playing Game (ARPG) elements are excelent as the various special abilities express variabilty in game mechanics while providing satisfying feedback in the form of crunchy-gory slaughter.  While there is plenty of good enemy variability throughout the campaign, your primary tactics will most likely not vary until you come accross large groups of enemies or platoons that mix range and melee combatants.

The character customization is limited to the items you wear and the sprawling skill tree that makes up the leveling system for the game.  While skill gems provide the meat of experience in terms of move sets, the skill tree simply determines what weapons and armor you can equip while providing percentage bonus to your damage and attack speeds.

All character classes are viable, however, it is important to note their specialties to best equip and advance your character for optimal slaying.  While the game is not necessarily difficult, deaths become common when you make haphazard or impatient mistakes to bring the fight to a large group of enemies.  Boss encounters can seem daunting at first, however, once you understand to eliminate their followers and then carefully avoid their primary attack, the fights become very manageable.

Path of Exile introduces some innovations or rather differing mechanics for bartering and potion use.  When you trade an item into a vendor, you recieve peices of identifying scrolls or alchemy gems that can be used to identify or make magic items respectively.  This displaces the importance of accumulated wealth into a more free form experimentation with getting better gear as you can often make a better item from a non-magical item and a few alchemy gems.  Potions are recharged from slaying enemies rather than consumed on an individual basis, which adjusts your tactics as you become heavily damaged.

Overall, I think Path of Exile is a great game, free-to-play or not.  I found it more engaging than Diablo III and Torchlight II, however, your experience might vary based on how the art style and story appeals to your tastes.  The game, though, is just fun and should be at least tried.

[GET ASAP]

reviewText:
Path of Exile is worthy of any action-RPG's fan's attention - especially since the game is free.  If one wishes to support the game developers, money can be spent for cosmetic changes and to increase your stash size, but neither are required to play the game.

While the passive skill tree is enormous, it does require a bit of thought and planning to be utilized effectively.  Active skills are socketed to items, allowing unique combinations and a large amount of variety to gameplay (although, some options are far more effective than others).  Skills are leveled through experience that your character gains as they are socketed in an equipped item.

Disadvantages...two in my experience: descynchronization from the required servers, even with ample internet capability; the targeting system is frustrating for melee type characters.  Both are irritating and exacerbate each other, often leading to character deaths.  As with Diablo 3 (the only other ARPG game that I have played with a server connection requirement), this has kept me from playing hardcore characters.  It's a shame, because I enjoy the challenge.

Overall, I will wholeheartedly recommend the game, despite the above-mentioned flaws.  The developer seems committed and responsive to the fans / supporters, which is a nice bonus and will hopefully ensure future changes which allow for better, more reliable gameplay.  Additionally, the amount of variety and different gameplay options (races, ladder servers, etc.) should keep long term players' attention.

reviewText:
Best action RPG out there right now, but not without its problems:

PoE requires too much dedication for hard working students and people with jobs or a family who want to maintain a healthy lifestyle. If you don't have a lot of time on your hands, you're better off playing some other game because you won't get much out of PoE.

The skill tree doesn't offer as much freedom as it first appears to. While the overall selection does greatly affect how your character works under the hood, they are still passive skills, most of which are just tiny percentage buffs and seriously underwhelming on their own.

I'm not a fan of D3, but the active skills in PoE do not satisfy like D3's do. There aren't any active skills that really make me want to build a PoE character.

In PoE you tend to build a character around one attack and spam that single one until you're blue in the face. Other action RPGs typically offer combined use of more active skills.

PoE is a thinking person's game, challenging, huge depth in its mechanics. It takes a long time and a lot of reading to learn how to create strong characters and it takes forever to get characters to a high level. The learning process is a joy, but respeccing isn't really doable.

The game changes a lot. If you leave the game and return after some months, you'll need to relearn wat makes a strong character, and all your character's passive skill trees will have been reset because the game's skill tree was likely updated. Your characters won't function until you reinvest those skillpoints. After returning to the game you likely won't know the current trade value of items.The game doesn't comfortably let you take a few months off and then come back.

They went too crazy with the socket colours and linked sockets. While fun at first, the impossibly low odds of getting the right sockets and links on your gear become an annoying limiting factor to how you build your character. Specifically, part of the problem is that the type of defence stat (armor, energy shield, or evasion) on a gear item determines what socket colour is most likely to show up on it. Active kills are gems that need to be socketed before you can use them, and they will only fit in sockets of the matching colour. This effectively forces you to focus on a specific defence type based on what active skills you want to use, severely restricting the endless freedom that the passive skill tree initially appears to provide.

reviewText:
If you like ARPGs and loved Diablo 2, but didn't like Torchlight, then this would definitely satisfy your need for a D2 style game. All active skills are based on resocketable gems, making you're character build your own, and the passive talent system is very reminscent of the sphere grid/tree/maze in FFX, which gives you even more lattitude in determining how you want to create your character over the long run.

Some downsides:
- Online only. This will cause you to have desync issues so you'll get some moments where you or monsters will teleport.
- Bit of a learning curve. You'll need to check a wiki to see how to get the most out of the merchants and how to use support gems).
- No character customization for appearance.

You really have nothing to lose by playing this game, so give it a few hours and get a feel for it.

reviewText: Path of Exile is undoubtedly one of the best free-to-play titles in recent years. If you're a fan of eerie & spine chilling, fantasy hack 'n' slash games where fighting huge mobs of ghastly creatures and ominous soldiers are the norm, Path of Exile is for you. As many have said already, this game has a very similar feel to the Diablo series and takes a large amount of influence from it (i.e. how the game is set into Acts and once you have completed them you can move onto harder difficulties), but also adds something of it's own into the mix such as having no currency in the game. Path of Exile is what Diablo 3 should have been and totally takes the cake between the two. The amount of content in the game is astounding and sometimes I can't believe that this game is free-to-play. Of course, you have your proverbial microtransactions but unlike other games, Path of Exile offers mostly non-competitive items for sale such as more character slots and guild options. Player vs. Player is another great element to the game and from what I have seen it contains 1 vs 1, 3 vs 3 and 6 vs 6 arenas though the matchmaking is a bit buggy when joining a queue. So, if you are looking for an overly addicting, loot driven, online hack 'n' slash game with tons of gore and brutality, download this game now! You won't regret it!

reviewText:
This game is the true spiritual successor to Diablo II. It has amazing complexity, and though it's not flawless, it's a great gameplay experience. If you want to use 2H axe as a ranger, go for it. If you want to shoot bows with a massive hulking marauder, do it. The game lets you play the way you want to play, but with some limitations that make the builds challenging and unique.

The economy is also done properly, with no gold, but with usable currency that are used for item modification. Keeps the economy in check and you don't end up with a stock pile of gold that has no real use other than Auction House and the like.

5/5. Simply awesome.

reviewText: POE is like no other dungeon crawler I've ever played. The passive tree and skill gems are such unique character building mechanics that they became my favorite part of the game. The currency system has been excellently designed too; each unit of value is not only  valuable because it is money but because currency itself is expendable for varying magical effects on your items, transportation etc. The graphics are beautiful and controls are easy to pick up/remappable.  Some monsters, especially dungeon bosses can be very challenging (not to mention on higher difficulties - Cruel, Merciless) and take multiple tries to beat. The game lets you spawn back into the dungeon with damage you've already dealt persisting on the bosses so eventually you can brute force it if that's what you want to do, unless you are on Hardcore, in which case - Permadeath. Home building is mainly a neat distraction and hub for the Masters you can use to more easily craft powerful gear. My only complaint is that progressing through the whole life of a character to the end game requires that you do the same quest/storyline several times in a sort of new game plus style. The storyline is not bad by any means, in fact the world lore and theme is pretty cool but it can start to get repetitive. One of the best things about it, I've never spent a single dime and I get the same gameplay that anyone else who spends money on it does, because the majority of purchases available, other than more stash room (not necessary they give you plenty) are cosmetic only.\n\nHighly highly recommend to anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers, and to anyone who hasn't tried one before, why not give it a shot? Free-2-Play after all.
