reviewText:
Path of Exile is a complex and engaging free to play action RPG set in the grim world of Wraeclast. The atmosphere is very dark and interesting. Players slowly uncover the secrets behind their exile and Wraeclast. The lore is scattered throughout the game world and really adds to the immersion.

The passive tree is absolutely massive and extremely diverse, allowing for almost any playstyle imaginable. Skills can be augmented with Support Gems" to significantly modify what they do and to create some truly outrageous combinations. The amazing unique items in the game only add to the already overwhelming amount of character customization. The result is a theorycrafter's wet dream.

Another major feature is that there is no "gold" as a form of currency. Instead there are numerous items of varying rarity that modify almost every aspect of items you find. These currency items allow players to custom tailor their gear while simultaneously combating inflation of the economy since they are consumed on use.

The game also features "Races"
date: which are timed competitve events ranging from a few minutes to a couple hours. Races can have many additional features and restrictions to make them more fun and challenging. Some races are designed to be almost an entire different game mode than the base game. Races are separated by Seasons
recommended: allowing players to earn points and win limited time alternate art unique items.\n\nOn top of all this
hoursPlayed: Grinding Gear Games is one of the most communicative developers I have ever experienced. They are very active in the community and take all suggestions and feedback seriously. Lastly
voteText: the game features a completely non pay to win microtransaction model. All game content is available right from the start. Real money will only buy you cosmetic effects to make your character look awesome and a few account features for convenience. I highly recommend trying out Path of Exile if you have even the slightest bit of interest in the genre."

reviewText:
This game is awesome.

I played Diablo II religiously for a little over a decade (a few breaks here and there..) but I had to quit after bots just COMPLETELY INFESTED Battlenet. I bought Diablo III and wish I didn't spend $60 on it ...I will never play it again. I thought my days of playing Action RPGs were over ......until I found Path Of Exile. Its like the ......spiritual successor to Diablo2 but with enough twists and a few drastic differences (THE SKILL TREE) to keep me hooked. The icing on the cake is that this game is FREE. LOVE IT.
Regardless, I highly recommend this game if you are into ARPGs, like Torchlight..or if you are a fan of classic Diablo games. It takes a little bit of time to get used to how the currency"/skill tree/item socket systems work but once you get the hang of it ...you'll see the genius behind it. I just dont have enough time to play this game ...or any of my games for that matter D:

9/10"

reviewText:
My game of choice when it comes to the top-down action RPG genre!

It acts like a true spiritual successor to Diablo 2, when I started playing I was so pleased at how the game handled and looked. It's gritty and grimey and it feels like a slog through the legions of hell.

Where the game really shines is the character creation and theorycraft aspects. You can spend a good hour or so deciding what kind of build you want and what sort of weapons and attacks you're going to use before even clicking that create a new character button. Thinking about how your passive stats and combination of attacks are all going to synergise with each other is all part of the fun. And yet if you don't want to do that it's fairly obvious where to go and what to get to make a successful build anyway (after a bit of practice)

Highly recommended if you're a fan of the Diablo games, and even with the whole PoE vs D3 e-war I'd still try both and see what suits you, they are inherently different games. (this one is a whole lot cheaper though)

reviewText:
One of the deepest modern RPGs and dungeon crawlers. Great graphics, great combat and feel, great look, great customization, great loot and skills. Very original with how you customize your character, and large diversity in ways to design your character, meaning you hear less (or not at all) about some magical cookie cutter build that you HAVE to use to be competitive.

Voice acting is also pretty good I find, with the option to find out the backstories of the world and its characters.

One of, if not the most generous Free-to-Play systems around, only behind maybe an open source game or some such similar thing. The market isn't shoved in your face, you wouldn't know it was there if you didn't look for it, and the devs don't scum the char slots or bank and inventory slots. You aren't uncompetitive if you don't pay, but you can get cool looking stuff if you do. It's based less on pressure and more on that you want to support Grinding Gear Games and give them money because they've made a fantastic game and asked nothing for it.

The league system is done really well, with a good economy and the updates and expansions add a lot of cool things, and more addicting loot to massacre armies over.

Also, lootsplosions FTW.

reviewText:
Do you like action RPGS like Diablo 2, Torchlight, and Titan Quest? Yes? Then look no futher than Path of Exile.  This game is free to play in every sense of the word.  All money you can potentially spend is on cosmetics and such.  If you like it, it is worth supporting them as they have made an enjoyable game that never hounds you to spend money.  One playthrough will take around 20-25 hours, but you will likey want to go back and choose a new character to play with.

The biggest difference with this game as opposed to other action RPGS is that the skill you have are tied to gems that you pick up and then slot into armor/weapons.  These gems level up by you using them.  You can unslot them and then reslot other gems as you see fit (they maintain their levels).  This allows you to really experiment with builds while not being restricted to specific skills or armor.

Just give it a go. You will like it!

reviewText:
Poked a dead body and a giant shield fell out of its stomach.

11/10 Would poke dead people again

But in all seriousness, this is a great game. It has a good community, enough players that you can always find a party to play with, but the game is just as much fun to play alone if soloing is more your style. it is COMPLETELY F2P, with the only paid content being cosmetics. The difficulty curve is just steep enough to be challenging, without repeatedly reducing you to pounding the keys and screaming incoherently into your mic. The controls and gameplay take some getting used to, but if you've played similar games before you should have no trouble. One thing i found interesting is that there is no in-game currency. Instead, items are purchased using a barter system that uses items you can find while playing, and these items have their own uses as well. You start out with one of six classes, which each have their own strengths and weaknesses. However, the skills and abilities of these classes are infinitly customizable, giving you the freedom to play however you want. The story is not the most detailed I've seen, not by a long shot, but it's definitely there. All in all, this is one of the best games I've played in a long time, and i would definitely recommend that you play it.

Serious rating: 9.5/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After spending a very large portion of the past 2 years of my life playing and thoroughly enjoying this game I thought I would write a little review on it.

This game innovates the ARPG genre in so many ways while remaining true to the genre's roots. The passive and skill gem system provide considerable customization and drive to improve your character, the visuals while not always AAA standards are fantastic and really help set the mood for the dark forsaken continent of Wraeclast.

I dont listen to the music often as I am typically on mumble with my guild, but the sound design is also fantastic, particularly the Scion character's voice acting, you can truly feel her passion/heartache at the right moments, the game's sound effect often clearly illustrate finer details of the game such as a pile of loot dropping, a unique item dropping or a critical strike.

With the frequent free content patches and the microtransactions that at the very most increase convenience make you well aware that these developers have the hardcore gamer's best interests at heart while still making the game accessible to newer and more casual players by involving the community in such things as game/build guides as well as a few podcasts that help you keep updated on what new patches mean and how the game's meta is shifting. On top of that the game's streaming community are mostly very helpful and educational with each streamer giving you something to take away and apply to your own character, whether it be one of Ziggyd's beginner guides or Havoc616 and Mathil's  attempts to farm the endiest endgame content imaginable or even Willywonka/Helman/Raizqt for their unique content, there is always something to learn.

If I had one complaint it would be that a few engine issues keep it from being perfect. oh, and there isnt enough time to do all the builds that I think up.

Thank you Grinding Gear Games for giving me such an amazing experience to share with my friends all across the globe.

reviewText:
Why is Path of Exile so good? First things first it is completely, 100% free to play. There are no lousy gimmicks to be seen here in PoE's microtransaction store, just pure cosmetic/fun items.

The gameplay is fantastic. Combat feels satisfying and varied between the different classes.  As of writing this I have tried the ranger, the templar, the shadow, and the witch. All of the game's classes share the same skill tree compromised of hundreds of different passive abilities; you have full freedom to make your unique class/build! Active abilities are in the form of socketable gems. They can be gained through quest rewards or can drop randomly off monsters. They also level up and become stronger as long as you have them equipped and continue to meet their requirements. The inventory system is much like Diablo 2's, and at first I was put off by this (being so limited and all). This actually makes the gameplay better in my opinion. Instead of hoarding loads of useless ♥♥♥♥, you only pick up what you need. Also, did I mention this game does not feature currency?  You won't be collecting gold from your slain monsters, but instead you will be picking up scrolls and orbs that do various things. These items can be used to barter with other players in-game, or to upgrade your own items.

I haven't finished the campaign yet, my highest level character being my ranger (she is roughly halfway through the 2nd act I believe), so I am not sure how long it is.  I'm still learning plenty about the game myself. One thing I can tell you for sure is that I'm having more fun with this game than any other action RPG I've played, period.

PROS:

-Completely free, no pay to win items or advantages can be gained through the cash shop
-Multiplayer or Solo, your choice
-Deep skill tree allowing for some great custom builds
-Interesting story with plenty of dialogue and lore
-A very generous 25 character slots
-Fun bartering system
-Extremely well optimized (I am playing on a buget dell laptop with Intel HD graphics)

CONS:

None! Download this game, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Path of exile is essentially an antithesis to Diablo 3, or as some would say, a true successor to Diablo 2. It takes the enjoyable formula of an ARPG, and increases the customisation tenfold by adding an open form skill tree, and skills (in the form of gems) that can be equipped by anyone, as long as they have the required attributes. Add in some really solid gameplay, art and the fact that this game is TRULY free to play (all purchases are cosmetic), and you have an amazing game only a download away.

reviewText:
One of the best free games out there. It's a Point and click style online Action RPG right up there with Diablo - and unlike Diablo III it isn't a sell out: no pay to win.
It has the largest (and yet very well balenced) skill tree you're likely to ever see and is generally quite flashed out.
It takes many interesting new approaches to alot of things that are generally kept unchanged across the genre - like a deep barter system instead of the usual coin and flasks that refill as you kill mobs instead of having to craete new potions every few minutes.
The makers are a small independent team of hardcore gamers based in New Zealand" and they "created Path of Exile as the game that we'd want to play ourselves."
And it really does play like that - a game a gamer would want to play
date: and not one that some AAA company decides that they should.\nI can only say: give it a try
recommended: you'll be hooked - it's free anyways.\n\n9.5/10"

reviewText: Path of Exile is undoubtedly one of the best free-to-play titles in recent years. If you're a fan of eerie & spine chilling, fantasy hack 'n' slash games where fighting huge mobs of ghastly creatures and ominous soldiers are the norm, Path of Exile is for you. As many have said already, this game has a very similar feel to the Diablo series and takes a large amount of influence from it (i.e. how the game is set into Acts and once you have completed them you can move onto harder difficulties), but also adds something of it's own into the mix such as having no currency in the game. Path of Exile is what Diablo 3 should have been and totally takes the cake between the two. The amount of content in the game is astounding and sometimes I can't believe that this game is free-to-play. Of course, you have your proverbial microtransactions but unlike other games, Path of Exile offers mostly non-competitive items for sale such as more character slots and guild options. Player vs. Player is another great element to the game and from what I have seen it contains 1 vs 1, 3 vs 3 and 6 vs 6 arenas though the matchmaking is a bit buggy when joining a queue. So, if you are looking for an overly addicting, loot driven, online hack 'n' slash game with tons of gore and brutality, download this game now! You won't regret it!

reviewText:
TL:DR – A fun, free, online, click, click, click RPG that’s light on story with enough things to do that will keep all but the most hardcore player interested (for a bit, at least).

I’ll just start with the greatest selling point of Path of Exile—no selling point. Free helps as most of the flaws don’t seem quite so harsh at that price. You’ll click on wave after wave of bad guy as you roll the loot piñata dice in hopes that this time the Staff of Iwin drops. Path of Exile is a fun little game that you’ll find yourself loading up from time to time to kill a couple of waves of bad guys before your wrist starts to hurt. 7/10.

The Good—
Free: Only costs bandwidth and time to download.
Characters: Lots of character classes.
Items: Lots of stuffs with skills being placed on gem drops to make the game different.
Grinding: Now with 10% less hamster wheel.
Online Community: Friends need only apply.
Leagues: Lots of different events and contests for frequent players.
Updates: Fairly often with new expansions and drastic changes to gameplay to keep the game interesting.

The Bad—
Repetitive: You better like killing snakes in the forest zone, because you’ll do lots of it.
Graphics: Not bad, but worse than the competition. Much worse.
Online: People who are not your friend will annoy you. Greatly.
In Game Purchases: Currently, this isn’t bad but things could easily be changed to bad and make the game not worth running.

reviewText: POE is like no other dungeon crawler I've ever played. The passive tree and skill gems are such unique character building mechanics that they became my favorite part of the game. The currency system has been excellently designed too; each unit of value is not only  valuable because it is money but because currency itself is expendable for varying magical effects on your items, transportation etc. The graphics are beautiful and controls are easy to pick up/remappable.  Some monsters, especially dungeon bosses can be very challenging (not to mention on higher difficulties - Cruel, Merciless) and take multiple tries to beat. The game lets you spawn back into the dungeon with damage you've already dealt persisting on the bosses so eventually you can brute force it if that's what you want to do, unless you are on Hardcore, in which case - Permadeath. Home building is mainly a neat distraction and hub for the Masters you can use to more easily craft powerful gear. My only complaint is that progressing through the whole life of a character to the end game requires that you do the same quest/storyline several times in a sort of new game plus style. The storyline is not bad by any means, in fact the world lore and theme is pretty cool but it can start to get repetitive. One of the best things about it, I've never spent a single dime and I get the same gameplay that anyone else who spends money on it does, because the majority of purchases available, other than more stash room (not necessary they give you plenty) are cosmetic only.\n\nHighly highly recommend to anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers, and to anyone who hasn't tried one before, why not give it a shot? Free-2-Play after all.

reviewText:
This game is the true spiritual successor to Diablo II. It has amazing complexity, and though it's not flawless, it's a great gameplay experience. If you want to use 2H axe as a ranger, go for it. If you want to shoot bows with a massive hulking marauder, do it. The game lets you play the way you want to play, but with some limitations that make the builds challenging and unique.

The economy is also done properly, with no gold, but with usable currency that are used for item modification. Keeps the economy in check and you don't end up with a stock pile of gold that has no real use other than Auction House and the like.

5/5. Simply awesome.

reviewText:
Forget what I said in 2k14, now THIS is the best Hack`n`Slash avaiable without any doubt.

+ True F2P without p2w microtransactions
+ Tons of new content delivered multiple times per year
+ Teoreticaly unlimited amout of possible builds. Full strength archer? Big-♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥ warrior with two-handed tree in his hands casting spells? Witch hitting enemies with her akimbo-style wands without any elemental damage? Imagination is the limit here.
+ Number of builds is even higher now due to Ascendancy expansion
+ No money, just exchange economy
+ Very polite community (with some exception - they are everywhere)
+ Low system requirements
+ Good graphincs and high quality soundtrack

- Bugs, bugs, bugs... last expansion bring the biggest amount of bugs ever included in this game, including very annoying disconnection and game crashes.
- Expensive microtransactions. Sometimes you want to support developers, but those skins are waaaay overpriced.
- Newbie unfriendly. You need to learn hard way how to play (or use tutorials - highly recommended).

reviewText: I am old as dirt, have played this game 4k+ hrs. It still fells new with every new char, every new challenge league. Our guild now has 28 members, spread over the whole world (of which I am the humble leader). Play it with friends, new or old, preferably over Skype or Teamspeak.\nJoin a guild if your old friends don't get it, or make your own guild and invite people you find nice in the game.  The community is mostly very nice. Immature (not young-age has nothing to do with it) or cocky players tend to quit, cause the learning treshold is quite high. Be nice ingame, and you will get all the help you need. Global chat can be a way to meet other players (or get trolled if you are unlucky), or just throw in some questions if you trade.\nTo summarise: PoE is a game that never gets old. Frustrating as hell sometimes, for sure, but never boring.

reviewText:
After spending a very large portion of the past 2 years of my life playing and thoroughly enjoying this game I thought I would write a little review on it.

This game innovates the ARPG genre in so many ways while remaining true to the genre's roots. The passive and skill gem system provide considerable customization and drive to improve your character, the visuals while not always AAA standards are fantastic and really help set the mood for the dark forsaken continent of Wraeclast.

I dont listen to the music often as I am typically on mumble with my guild, but the sound design is also fantastic, particularly the Scion character's voice acting, you can truly feel her passion/heartache at the right moments, the game's sound effect often clearly illustrate finer details of the game such as a pile of loot dropping, a unique item dropping or a critical strike.

With the frequent free content patches and the microtransactions that at the very most increase convenience make you well aware that these developers have the hardcore gamer's best interests at heart while still making the game accessible to newer and more casual players by involving the community in such things as game/build guides as well as a few podcasts that help you keep updated on what new patches mean and how the game's meta is shifting. On top of that the game's streaming community are mostly very helpful and educational with each streamer giving you something to take away and apply to your own character, whether it be one of Ziggyd's beginner guides or Havoc616 and Mathil's  attempts to farm the endiest endgame content imaginable or even Willywonka/Helman/Raizqt for their unique content, there is always something to learn.

If I had one complaint it would be that a few engine issues keep it from being perfect. oh, and there isnt enough time to do all the builds that I think up.

Thank you Grinding Gear Games for giving me such an amazing experience to share with my friends all across the globe.

reviewText:
After spending a very large portion of the past 2 years of my life playing and thoroughly enjoying this game I thought I would write a little review on it.

This game innovates the ARPG genre in so many ways while remaining true to the genre's roots. The passive and skill gem system provide considerable customization and drive to improve your character, the visuals while not always AAA standards are fantastic and really help set the mood for the dark forsaken continent of Wraeclast.

I dont listen to the music often as I am typically on mumble with my guild, but the sound design is also fantastic, particularly the Scion character's voice acting, you can truly feel her passion/heartache at the right moments, the game's sound effect often clearly illustrate finer details of the game such as a pile of loot dropping, a unique item dropping or a critical strike.

With the frequent free content patches and the microtransactions that at the very most increase convenience make you well aware that these developers have the hardcore gamer's best interests at heart while still making the game accessible to newer and more casual players by involving the community in such things as game/build guides as well as a few podcasts that help you keep updated on what new patches mean and how the game's meta is shifting. On top of that the game's streaming community are mostly very helpful and educational with each streamer giving you something to take away and apply to your own character, whether it be one of Ziggyd's beginner guides or Havoc616 and Mathil's  attempts to farm the endiest endgame content imaginable or even Willywonka/Helman/Raizqt for their unique content, there is always something to learn.

If I had one complaint it would be that a few engine issues keep it from being perfect. oh, and there isnt enough time to do all the builds that I think up.

Thank you Grinding Gear Games for giving me such an amazing experience to share with my friends all across the globe.

reviewText: Path of exile is essentially an antithesis to Diablo 3, or as some would say, a true successor to Diablo 2. reviewText:
I thought I would try and write up a few words about this game, as I really enjoy the ARPG games and played through most of them (Diablo I & II, Titan Quest & IT, Torchlight I & II, Van Helsing, and only don't have D3 due to cost - though this may change when the patch comes) and for me, the Daddy of them all has been Titan Quest. I probably sunk 200+ hrs in that and Immortal Throne (they don't show on my Steam games as I had them pre-steam and loved the game so much I rebought them on Steam) and played through the game on all three difficulty ratings.

So how does Path of Exile square up to these other great ARPG's? Bloody good actually. Really bloody good.

Graphics

The effects on everything are superb, the gem levelling, the elemental attacks, the frozen or burning mob/player effects, the animations for mobs blinking, tunnelling, dissolving, ghosting, all of it. The backdrops for locations (towns, villages, caves, forests, battlegrounds) are lush with a huge amount of detail, the characters look excellent, with a large amount of clothing variants.

Maps

Excellent. How many ways can you actually put dead ends into a seemingly open ended area? You will be surprised, and they do it very well. With some much detail, the minimap adds yellow 'corridors' to show connecting areas in case the foliage or camera angle is in your way, and there are plenty of variations - cave textures are repeated more often than not, but I suppose its quite hard to come up with new ways to portray rocks, so I will let them off that.

Mobs

A Huge amount of variation with the usual casters, fighters and ranged mobs, and then mixed abilities, casting, teleporting, swarms, etc. There is a nice mix of normal and yellow bosses, and then end of act bosses. I think I would have liked to see more 'bigger than yellow but less than end of act bosses' like in TQ, but other than that, jolly good indeed.

Skill Tree & Classes

Ah, the bread and butter of all ARPG's, the skill tree. This is where PoE fails, as it has no skill tree at all! Instead, it has a freaking skill WEB. No mere tree for this game, but a spiders web that depending on class, your start point changes. You gain skill points per level and for completing some quests and you can customise your (one of 6) classes to a stupid amount of variations. I thought TQ ability to combine two classes and then pick and choose from their respective trees brilliantly varied, but this is something else.

Loot

Ah, the loot. You want to pour of the minute of the items found, min/maxing to gain resists/hp/regen/dps? You will spend hours doing so. You want the ability to create and improve items? You will spend hours doing so. You want to take your item as you like the look of it, wipe it, and new stats, add sockets and reforge links? You will spend hours doing so.

Like most other ARPGs, you never seem to find the right item for your class, but this only makes you want to farm and then replay the whole game again on the next difficulty. There are sockets to add spells and effects to your attacks, and gems to improve the quality of the items - so the combinations of items available is staggering.

Overall

So add them all together and what have you got? A cracking game, and even diehard 'nothing will beat Titan Quest' ARPGers will admit that this is fantastic. The game itself is free, and you really do not need to spend a penny to enjoy it - I may drop some money on it to say thanks rather than any real need to want a shiny effect on my hat or glowing footprints (even though they do look smart) A fourth act or more locations per act may have tipped it over the edge, but this is right up there, surpassing both Torchlights and Van Helsing, and right on the tailcoats of TQ.

There is simply not an excuse to not download this on Steam right now.

reviewText:
Path of Exile is an ARPG with a heavy focus on lore, and the highest level of character customization I've ever seen. Within the seven classes, there are at least a couple hundred builds that are fundamentally different.

However, not only the playstyles of characters vary a lot, but the way enemies try to defeat you as well. The game progressively introduces concepts such as rogue exiles, enemies that use group skills, auras, shrines, ghosts haunting bosses, blood magic etc. that keep raising the difficulty while keeping it skill, and not gear-dependent.

In the endgame, players often find themselves making dozens of actions/decisions per second, dodging different projectiles, spells and charging monsters, using flasks, teleporting, modifying auras, applying curses in order to stay alive. Not only there are a lot of things to do once the main storyline is complete (after about 6 hours, plus another 10 for the next two difficulties), but simply fighting diverse endgame bosses is an exhilarating challenge in itself.

reviewText:
This game is pretty much the God-game of free-to-plays ever built. I'm not gonna go into too much specifics, but good-God, as my first time viewing the steam-store page, they really picked some deceptively scrolled-all-the-way-in and an obssession with lots of swirling and radially-ejecting spells. There is a bit of that in this game but I don't necessarily think the spell-groups displayed in the first screenshots really give an accurate feel for the game itself. Bite me.

TLDR:: For those of you who wanna cut straight to the cheese:

1] NOT pay-to-win (unless you count extra stash space... the only other form is cosmetics... not even exp boost)

2] The level of content, customizeablity, utility and versatility (spell gems), and amount of spell-gem combinations is quite honestly, somewhat staggering.

3] This is not the type of game you can play if you have kids. In other words it's really time consuming and you can screw-up really easy in Hardcore. So just be wary. Also be wary of some particularly toxic players who may try to rip you off or bully you, but 96% of people on here are okay people, friendly and are glad to help.

4] Don't troll excessively (everyone hates that) but make jokes about Jews or Feminism (or gays, and now transgender who knows), and you can pretty much gaurantee a strike on your account, and you don't want that.

5] Not going to really draw any conclusions based off my last point: but this is no pushover development company, and the certainly know what they're doing. PVP and loads of content, and an atom-bomb coming soon when they drop 2.0

reviewText:
+ seven characters

+ balancing
+ skill tree
+ many-faceted builds

reviewText: Although I'm no huge fan of hack'n'slash RPGs, PoE was the first game of this genre since long ago (since D2 I bet) which managed to keep me playing for longer than just a few hours. And on top of all that it's completely free! Free to play" but not "pay to win"

reviewText: Levo jugando desde el inicio de la beta (Febrero) y para mí es el mejor indie del año y el MMORPG de la decada. Es lo que Diablo 3 tenía que haber sido, los pequeños detallles, la cantidad de magias equilibradas, un PvP nivelado, y un high-end de lo más variado. 20 personas (ahora 33) owned Bizzard. Es una mezcla de grandes juegos (FFVII, FFX, Titanquest, Diablo 2, Neverwinter... más unas cuantas ideas propias (un árbol de +1000 pasivas, no existe moneda alguna, se fomenta el trade de objetos y orbes, no hay magias inútiles ni todo el mundo va con la misma build, puedes craftearte todo tu equipo según tu criterio, etc...). La filosofía que mantienen es PLAY 2 WIN y free to play. Si os molan los juegos difíciles y el hardcore gaming, ya sabéis. Sobretodo muchisimo contenido (cada semana meten cosas nuevas, arreglos y mejoras), los cálculos del loot y la mecánica del juego son públicos, escuchan las peticiones de la gente y las implentan... una auténtica maravilla. No sé si les cambiará la mentalidad, pero ahora tienen todo mi respeto. PD. Si os mola el juego pillarles algún pack (aspectos customizables de personajes y magias, entre otros)... para echarles un cable ;).

reviewText:
Path of Exile is a very deep ARPG with a rather unusual currency mechanic and a massive skill tree. It has a steep learning curve and can be somewhat punishing, but that's also what makes winning feel so rewarding.

The devs have kept their promise of making the game truly free. Most microtransactions confer cosmetic changes. The only microtransaction that actually affects gameplay is unlocking additional stash tabs (bank storage space). I found that when I only had one character, it was pretty easy to stay within the limits of the default 4 tabs. After a hundred hours of gameplay, I felt like a small payment to be able to hoard more items was more than justifiable (and a bit more to make my new character look super cool!).

The game is also kept interesting by regular challenge leagues where you start a new character in a separate game world with a fresh economy and different gameplay rules.

At a low low price of free, it's definitely worth a go!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the most addicting and rewarding Action Role Playing games to date. It features an extensive passive tree with over hundreds of possibilities with extreme character progression and builds.

The game features 7 different classes each with their own unique abilities and play styles which caters to any individuals type of play-through, whether you are a brute tank (The Marauder) or a necromancer witch who can use arcane magic and call upon the dead for help.

The best feature of the game is that it is free to play! There are in-game purchases but they're merely cosmetic items which don't effect the balancing of the game as the developers have been strict on making a fair game.

You will almost certainly have a good time leveling up with your friends.

As there is no gold in this game, You may get turned off by the extreme reliance on trading that is a consequence of the frustratingly unrewarding item drops and PoE's annoyingly random orb system

The game itself looks rather nice, even if it isn't up to par with the AAA games out there, it is a free to play and not 60$.

All in all, I'd say pick this one up! It's free after all and if you enjoy ARPG's then you'll enjoy this one!

reviewText: I can't imagine a more disappointing crafting mod for Fallout: New Vegas. While it introduces an interesting new set of crafting skills, it all comes down to luck. Still, it's a lot of fun to noodle around with, and definitely made my Fallout: New Vegas experience more realistic.

reviewText: This game is, in many ways, the true successor to Diablo II. That's not intended as a diss of D3 - plenty of fun to be had there. But Path of Exile takes the ground laid by D2 and extends it with a skill-crafting system that stands as one of the great accomplishments of the genre. The level of customization that is potentially open to a long-term player of PoE borders on the absurd, and we're not talking about cosmetics here. You craft your *abilities*, and if that notion strikes a chord with you, then you should get started playing this thing ASAP.\n\nIt's far from perfect. PoE suffers from an unfriendly new-player experience, a looooong on-ramp to The Awesome, and constant trouble with lag spikes leading to player deaths (yes, the game is 100% server-driven). But these annoyances will not interfere with the genre afficianado being entranced by how thoroughly this game has shown what a bit of creativity and hard work can do for a well-established genre.

reviewText:
+ Art style fits dark" and "realistic" theme perfectly.
+ Graphics are also technically great without performance issues.
+ Huge passive skill tree which leads to unlimited different playstyle.

+ Level design is OK. Game lenght is nice for players who seek a good campaign.
+ And the best; everything above is completely free. Not a single balance-destroying microtransaction. So there is almost nothing to complain."

reviewText: Path of exile is by far the most riveting and intriguing game I have ever played.  Through the variations of character selection and weapon/armor  types it is just absolutely superior to all other games.  Through my career of working for Riot games I have earned the opportunity to play and help design many variations of video games.  I truly believe that no other game compares to this one.  Path of exile is a game that you will not soon forget and will not easily get bored of. Path of exile leads you to many hours of action packed game play.  From the start of the game you are immediately thrown into action as you wash up on the shore and you find that everyone is dead around and you are surrounded by flesh eating zombies as well as many other creatures.  You have to fight your way through the unforgiving world as you collect new weapons, armor, stones, wands, and many other achievable items.  I believe that this is the best action RPG I have ever played.

reviewText: Downloaded on a whim, Absolutely fantastic, if u were disapointed with diablo 3 download this now,  if ur like me someone who has played some diablo (played the first 2 a little, mostly 3 not much tho), and torchlight 2 but cant get into it completely for whatever reason and always end up not coming back to it, this is the game for u, yes i just downloaded today, yes ive only played 5 hours, but for me downloading this with no real hope for it, i was extraordinarily delighted to find myself playing a game i could see my self playing next year, or the year after that. It is simply put, Fantastic, the creature design, the voice acting and the visuals are all on par (or succeed) the big games (torchlight, diablo(yee im talking u deckard cain), etc) by far. The way u earn abilities and equip them is one of the most original and inovative ways ive ever seen a game go about it, any class can use any weapon (as far as im aware so far on my adventure :P) now the question is (the question that may or may not be preventing u from downloading this game) is it pay to win? drum roll..... curtains open... NOPE, and for once its completely true,u wanna spend 50 bucks on some really good gear that will make u 10x better than any one else, well to bad mofo not gonna happen, anything in the game u buy with real money is purely cosmetic (except pets? not sure havent got one or played with anyone yet who has, so if u know please leave a comment) or for upgrades to your account (extra item tabs, extra character slots etc). anyway in conclusion if u are a fan (or like me not, but waiting for the right one) of these types of rpg action games, then download it now, its free so why not :P and it has definitely become my favorite game in this genre.

reviewText:
Path of Exile is not for everyone.

It's pretty much Diablo 2 with a watered down color palette, a less immersive setting, and a super intense skill tree... oh the skill tree! It deserved to be in a better game. It's beautiful!
http://www.pathofexile.com/passive-skill-tree
That web page contains everything you need to know about Path of Exile. Judge it and you judge the game.

I love the tree. I loved tinkering with possible builds on that website. I loved mapping out the path of my new Templar. I hated trudging through all the bland grind required to carry out the plan. For me, screwing around with the skill tree on their website was actually more fun than playing the game.

Their forums hint at an active community and substantial end-game content. If you have the patience to make it pay off, I'm certain you'll greatly enjoy PoE. But after 8 hours I'm uninstalling and not looking back.

Thumbs up for its small target audience.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Path of Exile is a FREE 2 PLAY!! action roleplaying hack and slash game comparable to the likes of Diablo 2 and the Dungeon Siege games. You play as an exile facing the harshness of the continent of Wraeclast, fighting enemies and exploring the land but mostly HOARDING items. The game allows to experience the story through 6 classes from the start plus another one that is unlocked by completing the storyline. It uses a third person or an overhead view and combat is lucid and unstiff. The world of Wraeclast is really beautiful, the dark artstyle compliments the tone. The skill tree is very diverse allowing vast customization of your character. The weapons are very diverse through different modifiers and items are tradable amongst players. The game has a PvP and Co-op options which allows you to interact with others or your friends through your journey across Wraeclast. Let's talk about the free2play model, it is not Pay2Win. Everything that you can purchase is cosmetics or stash space which does not affect the game. The game is regularly updated and devs seem very dedicated to the game. Rating: 92/100

reviewText:
You bloody kiwis, you've done it. This is the best thing that came out of NZ, since Peter Jackson.

Yes, the very famous description of Path of Exile is pretty accurate. This game IS what Diablo 3 should have been. Simply because Grinding Gear made some very brave decisions that Blizzard was too afraid to make.

Skill runes was on the table for D3 for a long time but Blizzard didn't go through with it. GG did and it paid off. It works perfectly and brings another dimension to looting. It's rewarding enough to make you stick with a set of skills and flexible enough to get you to try different things. Concept of linking gems is almost perfect and I love experimenting with it.

Removal of gold and the barter system is a very bold decision. A big name studio wouldn't have considered this because it makes the game too complicated for noobs and people who would want to buy their way through obstacles. It breaks the cycle of loot/sell and forces you to think about what you're going to do with your loot. I mean you can trade your Orb of Chances for an item you like or you can use them to get something better. It's a quite exciting concept for a purist looter.

Another bold decision which makes this game a little complicated for a newbie is the colossal passive skill tree. I think this decision is a clear indication of who GG's target audience for PoE. To be succesful, you have to study the whole skill tree and plan your route. You can't just randomly allocate points and hope to survive. Not many games nowadays, encourages players to actually think" and "plan". These words are considered "out of fashion" and "bad for business" in today's gaming world.

Yeah
date: these are pretty brave decisions but what is bolder than giving your precious game free and having only cosmetic microtransactions in it? As if the guys in Grinding Gear tried to do opposite of everything Blizzard did with D3. "Blizzard put a $70 price tag on the game and tried to suck even more money out of the games with their RMAH. Alright
recommended: let's make PoE free and have no way of buying success in this game." This is truly a noble strategy and because of this
hoursPlayed: first time I finished PoE during public beta
voteText: I felt that I owed these guys something. I bought cosmetic improvements for the first time in my gaming life and it felt bloody good. I will do it again as long as I keep playing the game.\n\nThe game is all round well polished and very skillfully executed. All the bold decisions I mentioned above made PoE truly a great game. But unfortunately
helpfulPercent: I wouldn't give it a 10/10.\n\nThere's one decision prevents me calling this game "perfect" and it's decision that doomed D3 from the start: Having to be online to play a single player campaign. You can give me the logical reasons behind this decision but none of them would be convincing enough to change my mind about this. I understand that it's a richer experience with a party and multiplayer is well integrated to the game
votesHelpful: but
votesTotal: I simply do not want lag during a single player campaign session. It's not so much of an issue at the start but once you make it to 60+ maps
votesFunny: lag/loss turns into your biggest enemy. I mean
commentsCount: it doesn't make it unplayable but it's quite annoying when I lose 15 mins of experience because of 1 second of lag. I can't see why this game cannot have an offline single player campaign and my rating will stay at 9/10 until this becomes the reality."

Through my career of working for Riot games I have earned the opportunity to play and help design many variations of video games.  I truly believe that no other game compares to this one.  Path of exile is a game that you will not soon forget and will not easily get bored of. Path of exile leads you to many hours of action packed game play.  From the start of the game you are immediately thrown into action as you wash up on the shore and you find that everyone is dead around and you are surrounded by flesh eating zombies as well as many other creatures.  You have to fight your way through the unforgiving world as you collect new weapons, armor, stones, wands, and many other achievable items.  I believe that this is the best action RPG I have ever played.

reviewText: LVL 40+ character and just started cruel difficulty. For a free game it does everything right in the microtranaction department. I haven't spent any money on the game and I have put a lot of time into it. The party function is extremely easy as there is a billboard in the town centre to organise it quickly and I was able to defeat the end boss with a party of 6. Even at the level I am at, I am still striving for the perfect build with my witch/summoner.

reviewText: Really fun game! Gorgeous levels, fun skills (and even more fun skill tree, if you happen to like Final Fantasy 10), and totally free. You can support the game with microtransactions, which you may really be compelled to do after realizing this game's replayability.\n\nThere are points in the game where you're going to have to rush into rooms full of like 30 glowing, pumped up monsters cosplaying as rich TF2 players to take away their buffs which are hiding SOMEWHERE and that is totally terrifying, but fun, and even more fun if you're playing with multiple people so you can portal right back. One of the levels straight up made me miserable that I couldn't call in a tactical air strike and just wipe it out, though.
